ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Mayor and council, § 1-36 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - Rules and regulations adopted. 
    That certain document entitled "Personnel Rules and Regulations, Town of Gilbert," three copies of which are on file in the office of the clerk, and as may be hereafter amended, is hereby adopted by the council and made a part of this section by reference as the personnel rules and regulations of the town. Personnel rules and regulations may be amended by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1984, § 3-11-1; Ord. No. 1065, § I, 11-11-97; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13) 
Sec. 2-32. - Fingerprinting of prospective applicants. 
    Each applicant for town employment shall provide to the chief of police or his designee, fingerprint identification. The chief of police or his designee shall, pursuant to A.R.S. § 41-1750 and Public Law 92-184, section 902, forward those fingerprints accompanied by appropriate fees to the state department of public safety and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the purpose of seeking criminal history information on such applicant. Information obtained shall be used only for the purpose of evaluating the fitness of prospective employees of the town and shall otherwise remain confidential. 
(Ord. No. 925, § I, 3-28-95) 
Secs. 2-33-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MANAGER 

Sec. 2-51. - Office created. 
    The office of the manager is hereby created. The manager shall be appointed by a majority vote of the council for an indefinite term. The manager shall be chosen on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications and his knowledge of accepted practice with respect to the duties of his office as set forth in section 2-58. The manager may be removed with or without cause by the council by majority vote of the membership of the council, and the action of the council in removing the manager shall be final. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-1) 
Sec. 2-52. - Residence. 
    At the time of appointment, the person so appointed as manager need not be a resident of the town or the state, but within a reasonable amount of time after his appointment he shall reside within the town. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-2) 
Sec. 2-53. - Eligibility. 
    No member of the council shall be eligible to be appointed to the office of manager during the term for which the member shall have been elected. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-3) 
Sec. 2-54. - Bond. 
    The manager shall furnish a surety bond as may be set periodically by the council. Such bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of his duties as described in this division. Any premium for such bond shall be a proper charge against the town. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-4) 
Sec. 2-55. - Compensation. 
    The manager shall receive such compensation as may be set by the council from time to time. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-5) 
Sec. 2-56. - Deputy town manager. 
    The manager may appoint one or more deputy town manager(s) who shall serve at the pleasure of the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2648 , § I, adopted Feb. 15, 2018, amended § 2-56 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-56 pertained to assistant town manager and derived from Ord. No. 2561 , § I, adopted Nov. 19, 2015. 
Sec. 2-57. - Acting town manager. 
    In the event of the absence or unavailability of the manager, his powers and duties shall be performed by the following officers of the town and they are so appointed in the following order as each succeeding officer may be absent or unavailable: 
(1)  Deputy town manager(s) (in the order as provided in this section). 
(2)  Police chief. 
(3)  Fire chief. 
(4)  Finance and management services director. 
    In the event there is more than one deputy town manager, the manager shall maintain with the town clerk a list identifying the order of succession for each deputy town manager. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-7; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2561, § I , 11-19-15; Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Sec. 2-58. - Powers and duties. 
    The manager shall be the chief administrative officer and head of the administrative branch of the town. He shall be responsible to the council for the proper administration of all affairs of the town and shall have the power and be required to: 
(1)  Direct the office of the town manager in accordance with this Code and execute, on behalf of the council, general administrative supervision and control of the affairs of the town. 
(2)  Attend meetings of the council with a duty of reporting on or discussing any matter concerning the affairs of the departments, board, services or activities under his supervision, upon which, in his judgment, the council should be informed. 
(3)  Appoint and, when necessary, suspend and remove all employees of the town except appointed officials pursuant to the personnel rules and regulations, this Code, and ordinances of the town. 
(4)  In addition to the departments created pursuant to section 2-131, create such departments and offices he deems necessary for the governance of the town consistent with the funds and total personnel included within the adopted budget. 
(5)  Coordinate the administrative functions and operations of the various departments, boards, divisions and services of the town government, and on its behalf, carry out policies, rules, regulations, ordinances and provisions of this Code relating to the administration of the affairs of such departments, boards, divisions or services. 
(6)  Cause to be prepared and submitted to him by each department, board, division or service of the town government, itemized annual estimates of expenditures required by them for capital outlay, salaries, wages and miscellaneous operating costs; complete same into a preliminary consolidated town budget; and submit the same to the council annually on the dates specified by them, with his recommendation as to any increases, cancellations, transfers or changes in any of these items included in the preliminary budget. 
(7)  Supervise the expenditures of all departments, divisions or services of the town government. 
(8)  Analyze and supervise the functions, duties and activities of the various departments, boards, and services of the town government and of all employees thereof, and consistent with the authority and powers designated in this article, as in his judgment will result, if implemented, in the greater efficiency of the overall operation of the town government. 
(9)  Develop and organize necessary improvement projects and programs and aid and assist the council and the various departments and boards in carrying the same through to a successful conclusion. 
(10)  Make or cause to be made and keep a current inventory of all the personal and real property owned by the town and recommend to the council the purchase of new machinery, equipment and supplies whenever, in his judgment, the same may be obtained under terms and conditions which are most advantageous to the town. 
(11)  Make, or cause to be made, studies and surveys of the duties, responsibilities and work of the personnel employed by the town, including the abolition, consolidation, transfer or removal of positions or personnel whenever, in his judgment, such action would result in increased administrative efficiency. 
(12)  Execute and terminate easements, consent to use easements, rights-of-way, licenses, utility agreements, leases, use agreements, and other documents on behalf of the town that are necessary for and of benefit to public improvements previously approved by the town council or necessary to allow utility services access to town property; 
(13)  Execute and terminate reimbursement agreements (in amounts that do not exceed $100,000.00), assurance of construction documents, consent documents relating to property owners associations, documents required to preserve the town's interests relating to active or potential litigation, and confidentiality agreements, so long as such confidentiality agreements are made subject to the provisions of the state public records laws. 
(14)  Ensure that all laws and ordinances of the town are duly enforced. 
(15)  Devote his full time to the discharge of official duties. 
(16)  Perform such other duties as may be required of him by the council not inconsistent with the laws of the state or the provisions of this Code and ordinances of the town. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-8; Ord. No. 2293, § I, 7-27-10; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Sec. 2-59. - Policymaking. 
    The manager shall not exercise any policymaking or legislative functions, nor attempt to commit or bind the council to any action, plan or program requiring the official action of the council. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-9) 
Sec. 2-60. - Agreements on employment. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as a limitation on the power or authority of the council to enter into any supplemental agreement with the manager delineating additional terms and conditions of employment not inconsistent with the provisions of this division or of state statutes. 
(Code 1984, § 3-1-10) 
Sec. 2-61. - Authority to settle claims. 
(a)  The manager is authorized to negotiate and settle on behalf of the town claims and disputes brought by the town and claims and disputes brought against the town, its officers, appointees and employees, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The manager has investigated questions of liability and damages raised by the claim and has determined a reasonable dollar value of the claim. 
(2)  The claim and any proposed settlement has been reviewed and recommended by the town attorney and the risk manager. 
(3)  The settlement is conditioned upon an appropriate written release by the claimant in a form approved by the town attorney. 
(b)  The settlement authority of the manager is limited as follows: 
(1)  For claims against the town which are covered by the town's insurance, the manager is authorized to pay any deductible or self-insured retention assessed by the insurance carrier, contingent upon the review and approval of the town attorney; 
(2)  For claims presented to the town or disputes involving the town, the town manager shall have authority to settle such claims and disputes for an amount not to exceed $25,000.00. Such settlements shall be reviewed and approved by the town engineer (for easement and property acquisitions and condemnation actions initiated by the town only) and the town attorney. 
(c)  In light of confidentiality requirements related to transaction privilege tax matters, the limitation set forth in subsection (b)(2) above shall not apply to settlements of transaction privilege tax disputes and appeals and the manager has authority to approve settlement of such disputes and appeals in any amount he deems reasonable in the circumstances upon the recommendation of the finance and management services director and the town attorney. No settlement that reduces a taxpayer's tax liability in excess of $100,000.00 shall be approved by the town manager without a written waiver of confidentiality by the taxpayer authorizing release of the settlement amount to the council. 
(d)  Settlement of all other claims which cannot be resolved within the parameters set forth above shall be submitted to the council for review and approval or denial. 
(e)  Except for settlements approved pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, the manager shall submit to the council, a quarterly report of all claims settled by the town manager. 
(Ord. No. 1526, § I, 11-11-03; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Sec. 2-62. - Meet and confer. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the following meanings, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized representative means any individual who has been designated pursuant to this section to act on behalf of an employee organization. 
    Budget year means the annual budget term as set forth in state law. 
    Day means a business day, which is Monday through Friday excluding town recognized holidays, except as otherwise stated. 
    Employee means a full-time or regular part-time employee, but shall exclude contract, temporary, seasonal, or probationary employees. 
    Employee organization means an organization whose primary purpose is to represent employee groups, as described in subsection (b), for the purposes of the meet and confer process. An employee organization is not limited to an employee organization that has been designated by the town as the official and exclusive employee organization. 
    Impasse means the failure of the designated representative of the town and the representative of an employee organization to achieve agreement during the meet and confer process. 
    Managerial employee means any employee involved in formulating, determining, or effectuating policies on behalf of the town, or any employee having a major role in employee-employer relations on behalf of the town, or any employee providing direct assistance in the foregoing functions. 
    Mediation means efforts by a mediator to assist in reconciling a dispute of an issue initiated under the meet and confer ordinance between the town manager and the authorized representative of an official and exclusive employee organization through interpretation, suggestion and advice. 
    Mediator means a neutral and impartial third party. 
    Meet and confer means the performance of the mutual obligations of the town through its town manager and the designated representative of an official and exclusive employee organization to negotiate in good faith with respect to wages, hours and working conditions as set forth in subsection (f). 
    Memorandum of understanding ("MOU") means a written document agreed to by the town manager and representatives of an official and exclusive employee organization that has been approved by the town council. 
    Official and exclusive employee organization means an employee organization that has been designated by the town as described in subsection (e) herein. 
    Strike means concerted action of employees and/or others: (1) resulting in the failure of employees to report for work when directed to do so; (2) the concerted absence of employees from their positions; (3) the concerted stoppage of work and/or concerted slow down of work; (4) mass picketing which attempts by force of numbers to prevent ingress and egress from the picketed site, whether or not the picketing occurs during normal hours of operation; or (5) the concerted effort, in whole or in part, by any group of employees from the full, faithful, and proper performance of the duties of employment with the town. 
    Supervisory employee means an employee having authority to hire, transfer, suspend, lay off, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward or discipline other employees, or the responsibility to direct them in all major work aspects, or to adjust their grievances, or effectively to recommend such action, if in connection with the foregoing, the exercise of such authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature, but requires the use of independent judgment in conformance with the town's personnel rules and administrative procedures. 
    Town management means the town manager, deputy town managers, department directors and/or their designees or representatives. 
    Wages, hours and working conditions means topics limited to the following: 
(1)  Salary, wage rates, and shift differential; 
(2)  Overtime, compensatory time, stand-by, certification, and callout pay; 
(3)  Paid time off, including sick leave, vacation leave, injury leave, bereavement leave, jury duty leave, and holiday leave and pay; and 
(4)  Items of concern mutually agreed upon by an official and exclusive organization and the town manager. 
(b)  Employee groups. There shall be only three recognized employee groups within the town: 
(1)  Fire fighters, all classifications up to and including the rank of captain; 
(2)  Police officers, all classifications up to and including the rank of sergeant; and 
(3)  Except as otherwise set forth in subsections (1) and (2) above, employees who are not: 
a.  Managerial employees; 
b.  Confidential employees; 
c.  Supervisory employees; 
d.  Judges and elected officials; 
e.  The town clerk; or 
f.  Any member of a town board or commission. 
(c)  Rights of employees and employee organizations. 
(1)  Employees have the right to participate or engage in activities on behalf of an employee organization and have the right to refrain from such activities. 
(2)  Employees shall be free from any interference, restraint, or coercion by any employee, supervisor, manager, or representative of an employee group or employee organization. 
(3)  There shall be only one official and exclusive employee organization for each employee group for purposes of meet and confer. No employee shall be prohibited from exercising any rights the employee may have to meet with town management consistent with personnel rules and regulations or any town manager directive, regardless of whether the employee belongs to an employee organization. 
(4)  Employee organizations may use bulletin boards designated by town management for employee organization business in compliance with rules established for town bulletin boards by town management. 
(5)  Notwithstanding other penalties provided in this section, violations of employees' rights described in subsection (1) and (2) above by town employees will result in disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(d)  Rights of town management. 
(1)  The council is recognized as the policy-making body of the town. None of its actions or decisions shall serve as a basis for, or be evidence of, an unfair labor practice or other violation of this section. 
(2)  All decision-making authority shall rest with the town manager and council. Management rights include the right to: 
a.  Determine the levels of service needed by the community and to plan and provide those levels of service; 
b.  Determine the services, supplies and equipment necessary to continue uninterrupted operations and to determine the methods and processes of carrying out those operations; 
c.  Determine standards of service to be offered to the public and exercise control and discretion over its organization and operations; 
d.  Determine the overall goals, objectives, and policies affecting town programs; 
e.  Determine the purpose of each of the town's departments; 
f.  Determine the size of the town's management, organization, its functions, authority, amount of supervision and table of organization; 
g.  Determine the location of town facilities, including the establishment or relocation of buildings, divisions or subdivisions thereof, and the relocation or closing of offices, departments, divisions or subdivisions, buildings or other facilities; 
h.  Determine the financial policies, including all accounting procedures and all matters pertaining to finance; 
i.  Determine whether goods or services should be made, provided, leased, contracted for, or purchased on either a temporary or permanent basis; 
j.  Direct, supervise, control, and evaluate the departments, units, and programs and services of the town; 
k.  Direct, appoint, employ and assign officers, agents and employees of the town and to determine the standards therefore; 
l.  Direct the working forces, including the right to hire, promote, discipline, transfer, and determine the size of workforce; 
m.  Hire all employees and to determine their qualifications and fitness for employment and conditions for their continued employment or their dismissal; 
n.  Award promotional positions to the most qualified candidates; 
o.  Discipline and terminate employees for unacceptable performance or misconduct; 
p.  Classify the various positions of the town and prescribe duties and standards of productivity therefore; 
q.  Develop and determine levels of staffing and training; 
r.  Assign and apportion overtime, including the authorization for any full-, part-time, or contract labor; 
s.  Adopt reasonable rules and regulations; and 
t.  Take all necessary actions to maintain uninterrupted service to the town and its residents. 
(e)  Approval of MOU. The town council shall either accept, reject, or modify the proposed MOU. The council's decision on the proposed MOU is final. 
(1)  In the event the town council accepts the proposed MOU, then the MOU shall be effective for the term of the agreement. 
(2)  In the event a proposed MOU is not acted upon or rejected by the town council prior to the date set by law for adoption of the town's preliminary annual budget, then any wage established in said budget shall apply. 
(3)  In the event a proposed MOU is not acted upon or rejected by the town council prior to the date set by law for adoption of the town's preliminary annual budget, then the town's personnel rules and regulations regarding hours and working conditions shall apply and shall be in effect for subsequent budget years unless an MOU is reached pursuant to this section. 
(f)  Breach of memorandum of understanding. 
(1)  If there is a claim of breach of MOU and that MOU does not provide a process for resolution of the breach, the process outlined in subsections (2) or (3) below shall apply. If the matter is submitted for resolution to the council either through the breach process established in this subsection or a breach process established in an MOU, the decision of the council shall be consistent with this Code and final and binding upon the parties. 
(2)  In the event that there is a claim of breach of MOU that has not been resolved and the alleged breach involves a strike as defined in subsection (a), the matter shall immediately be referred to town council for resolution through a special meeting at the town council's earliest convenience. 
(3)  In the event that there is a claim of breach of MOU in all matters other than a strike as defined in subsection (a) that has not been resolved, the parties shall: 
a.  Within five days of the alleged breach, the party alleging the breach shall give written notice to the party who has allegedly breached the MOU. The notice shall specify the provision(s) breached and the facts and evidence demonstrating or supporting the breach; 
b.  A written response to the alleged breach shall be submitted to the party alleging the breach within five days of the written notice; 
c.  Within ten days of the written response, the parties shall meet and attempt to resolve the matter; and 
d.  If the meeting referred to in subsection (c)(3) above is successful, a written agreement which is intended to resolve the matter shall be signed by the parties and submitted to the council at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
e.  If the parties are unable to resolve the matter, all written materials submitted in subsections a. and b. above shall be submitted for resolution to the council. 
(g)  Conflicts. In the event there is a conflict between the town's personnel rules and regulations and an effective MOU, the MOU applies. 
(h)  Prohibited practices. 
(1)  Under no circumstances shall a town employee, official and exclusive employee organization, or any other individual or employee organization engage in, instigate, promote, cause, sponsor, condone, permit, encourage, or take part in any strike, slowdown, sympathy strike, withholding of services, work stoppage, picket, curtailment of work, reduction of work, or interference of any kind with the operations of the town. 
(2)  In the event of a violation of subsection (1) above, an employee organization shall immediately instruct the involved employees that their conduct is in violation of this section and/or any applicable MOU; that the employees may be disciplined up to and including termination; and instruct all such persons to cease the prohibited conduct and take all reasonable means to end the breach. 
(3)  Under no circumstances shall a town employee, official and exclusive employee organization, or other employee organization: 
a.  Discriminate against an employee with regard to employee organization membership because of race, color, religion, age, disability, sex, or national origin; 
b.  Discriminate against an employee because he has chosen not to join or assist an employee organization; 
c.  Except as provided in subsection (c)(5), use town time, property or equipment for employee organization business; 
d.  Obstruct, restrain or coerce any employee, elected or appointed town official in the exercise of any right provided by the provisions of this section; 
e.  Obstruct, restrain, threaten or coerce any elected or appointed official, representative of the employer or town employee for the purpose of gaining a concession; 
f.  Refuse to meet and confer in good faith with the town manager; or 
g.  Refuse or fail to comply with any provision of this section. 
(4)  Town management and its representatives shall not: 
a.  Discriminate against an employee with regard to terms and conditions of employment because of the employee's membership in an employee organization; 
b.  Obstruct, restrain or coerce any employee in the exercise of any right provided under this section; 
c.  Dominate or obstruct the designation or administration of any employee organization; 
d.  Discriminate in regard to hiring or any term or condition of employment in order to encourage or discourage membership in an employee organization; 
e.  Terminate or otherwise discriminate against an employee because he has signed or filed a petition, grievance or complaint or because an employee is forming, joining or choosing to be represented by an employee organization; 
f.  Obstruct, restrain or coerce any employee, elected or appointed town official, representative of the official and exclusive employee organization, for the purpose of gaining a concession; 
g.  Coerce the official and exclusive employee organization in the selection of its agent for meet and confer or adjustment of grievances; or 
h.  Refuse to meet and confer in good faith with an official and exclusive employee organization. 
(5)  The use of working time for the solicitation of members, dues and other employee organization business is prohibited. 
(6)  The use of work areas and the use of town equipment and information systems for the solicitation of members, dues, and distribution of other employee organization business is prohibited, except as otherwise provided in subsection (c)(5). 
(7)  Any conduct that constitutes prohibited practices under this section shall be grounds for discipline up to and including termination. 
(8)  Under no circumstances shall any individual not employed by the town or employee organization not recognized by the town obstruct, restrain, threaten or coerce any employee, elected or appointed town official. 
(9)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided for in section 1-5 of this Code and state and federal law. 
(h)  Sunset provision. All terms of this section shall automatically terminate on June 30, 2014. In no event shall an MOU's term extend beyond June 30, 2014. 
(Ord. No. 2085, § I, 11-13-07; Ord. No. 2090, § I, 12-4-07; Ord. No. 2147, § I, 7-29-08; Ord. No. 2265, § I, 11-17-09; Ord. No. 2352, § I, 12-15-11; Ord. No. 2429, § I, 5-16-13; Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Secs. 2-63-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CLERK 

Sec. 2-81. - Creation of office; appointment; duty and responsibility generally. 
    The office of the clerk is created and established. The clerk shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the council. It shall be the duty of the clerk, or his deputy or designee, to attend all meetings of the council unless by request he is excused therefrom by the mayor individually or by the council. The clerk shall be responsible for recording minutes and presenting them to the council for approval. 
(Code 1984, § 3-2-1) 
Sec. 2-82. - Bond. 
    Before entering upon his duties of office, the clerk shall furnish a surety bond in an amount as is provided by statute, conditioned upon faithful performance of his duties as such clerk, which bond shall be approved by the council. 
(Code 1984, § 3-2-2) 
State Law reference- Bonds of officers, A.R.S. § 9-302. 
Sec. 2-83. - Specific duties. 
    The duties of the clerk shall be as follows: 
(1)  Signatures. The clerk shall seal and attest all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require the formality. 
(2)  Treasurer. The clerk shall delegate the duties of treasurer of the town to the finance and management services director, who shall have the care, control and custody of the money of the town. 
(3)  Agendas. The clerk shall prepare the agenda of council meetings. 
(4)  Elections. The clerk shall be in charge of and responsible for the conduct of all town elections. 
(5)  Records management. The clerk shall be the custodian of all town records, as follows: 
a.  Documents not assigned to other officers. The clerk shall be custodian of all documents belonging to the town which are not assigned to the custody of some other officer. The clerk may delegate to the director of a department or office the duties of custodian of records for that department or office as appropriate. 
b.  Maintenance of indices. The clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index to all documents and records kept by him, so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had. 
c.  Maintenance of official documents and records. The clerk shall oversee the maintenance of all official documents and records of the town. 
(6)  Additional duties. In addition to the duties provided in this section, the clerk shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1984, § 3-2-3; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13) 
State Law reference- Clerk to serve as treasurer, A.R.S. § 9-238; records management and inspection, A.R.S. § 41-1346 et seq. 
Secs. 2-84-2-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TOWN ATTORNEY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2426, § I, adopted May 2, 2013, renumbered former div. 4, Indemnification, as div. 5 and set out a new division 4 as included herein. 

Sec. 2-90. - Creation of office; appointment; duty and responsibility generally. 
    The office of the town attorney is created and established. the town attorney shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the council. It shall be the duty of the town attorney to attend all meetings of the council; prepare or review all ordinances, contracts and similar documents for consideration by the council; provide legal advice to the council and all officers, departments, and employees in matters relating to their official powers and duties; retain special counsel with the concurrence of the town manager; and collaborate with other attorneys engaged by the council to manage litigation or assist the town attorney therein. 
(Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13) 
Secs. 2-91-2-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INDEMNIFICATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note- See editor's note at div. 4. 
State Law reference- Liability of councilmembers for acts of town officers or employees, A.R.S. § 9-255. 

Sec. 2-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means officers, employees, town councilmembers and members of committees, commissions, and boards of the town. 
    Proceedings means any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or proceeding, whether civil, criminal, administered or investigated. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-102. - Persons to be indemnified. 
    Any person made a party or threatened to be made a party to any proceeding by reason of the fact that such person is an officer, employee, councilmember or member of a board or commission of the town shall be indemnified as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-2) 
Sec. 2-103. - Prerequisite; notification of manager. 
    As a prerequisite to indemnification under this division, a person shall notify the manager as soon as he is made a party or threatened to be made a party to any proceeding. 
Sec. 2-104. - Action other than by or in the right of town. 
    If the proceeding is one other than an action by or in the right of the town, such person shall be indemnified against his expenses, including attorney's fees and judgments, fines, amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him in connection with such proceeding. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-3) 
Sec. 2-105. - Criminal proceedings. 
    If the proceeding is a criminal proceeding, the person shall be indemnified if he had no reasonable cause to believe his conduct was unlawful. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-4) 
Sec. 2-106. - No presumption created. 
    With respect to indemnification under section 2-104 or 2-105, a termination of the proceeding by judgment, order, settlement, conviction, or upon a plea of nolo contendere or its equivalent, shall not by itself create a presumption that the person acted, or failed to act, other than in good faith and in a manner which he reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interest of the town, and with respect to any criminal proceeding, had reasonable cause to believe that his conduct was unlawful. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-5) 
Sec. 2-107. - Action by or in the right of town. 
    If the proceeding is one by or in the right of the town to procure a judgment in the town's favor, the person shall be indemnified against his expenses, including attorney's fees, but excluding judgments and fines, and except as set forth in this division, amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him in connection with the defense or settlement of such proceeding if he acted, or failed to act, in good faith and in a manner he reasonably believed to be in or not opposed to the best interest of the town. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-6) 
Sec. 2-108. - Negligence and misconduct. 
    No indemnification under section 2-107 shall be made in respect of any claim, issue or matter as to which such person shall be adjudged to be liable for negligence or misconduct in the performance of his duty to the town. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-7) 
Sec. 2-109. - Success on the merits. 
    To the extent that a person covered by this division has been successful on the merits or otherwise in defense of any proceeding covered by this division or in the defense of any claim, issue or matter therein, he shall be indemnified against expenses, including attorney's fees, actually and reasonably incurred by him in connection therewith. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-8) 
Sec. 2-110. - Determination by council. 
    Any indemnification made pursuant to this division shall be made by the town only as authorized in the specific case upon a determination that indemnification of the officer, employee or councilmember is proper in the circumstances because he has met the applicable standard of conduct set forth in this division. Such determination shall be made by any of the following: 
(1)  By the council by majority vote of a quorum consisting of councilmembers who were not party to the proceeding. 
(2)  If a quorum is not obtainable, then by a written opinion of independent legal counsel acquired by majority of the disinterested councilmembers for that purpose. 
(3)  If there are not disinterested council- members, then by a declaratory judgment action brought in the superior court, declaring the rights of the officer, employee or councilmember to be indemnified pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-9) 
Sec. 2-111. - Indemnification not deemed exclusive remedy. 
    The indemnification provided by this division shall not be deemed exclusive of any other rights to which those indemnified may be entitled. The indemnification provided by this division shall be supplemental to and excess to any valid and collectible insurance coverage. 
(Code 1984, § 2-6-10) 
Secs. 2-112-2-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENTS[5] 
Footnotes:

No. 1363, § I.1., adopted Aug. 21, 2001; Ord. No. 1504, § I, adopted July 22, 2003; Ord. No. 1511, § I.1., adopted Sep. 16, 2003; Ord. No. 1525, § I, adopted Oct. 28, 2003; Ord. DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-131. - Establishment. 
    The following departments are established as departments of the town: 
(a)  Finance and management services department. 
(b)  Public works department. 
(c)  Development services department. 
(d)  Parks and recreation department. 
(e)  Police department. 
(f)  Fire and rescue services department. 
(g)  Town prosecutor department. 
(Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13) 
Sec. 2-132. - Administration. 
(a)  Appointment of directors. Each department shall be administered by a director appointed by and subject to the direction and supervision of the town manager. 
(b)  Organization. Department directors may establish divisions within their departments, consistent with the annual budget adopted by the council. 
(Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13) 
Sec. 2-133. - Duties of departments. 
(a)  The manager shall, by directive to each department director, designate the duties and responsibilities of each department. 
(b)  In addition to the manager's directives set forth in subsection (a) above, the following specific delegations of authority are hereby made, to be exercised through the director of such departments: 
(1)  The finance and management services department is authorized to pay lawful bills in accordance with appropriations of the council. 
(2)  The finance and management services department is authorized to administer the town's tax compliance program in accordance with chapter 58 of this Code. 
(3)  The development services and public works departments are authorized to enforce the provisions of town codes and ordinances. 
(4)  The public works department is authorized to accept on behalf of the town dedications of property and easements that are required to be dedicated pursuant to the land development code or a capital improvements project previously approved by the council. 
(5)  The public works department may purchase easements and real property with a purchase price of less than $10,000.00 if the purchase price is supported by evidence of similar prices for similar property or easements. 
(6)  The police department is authorized to enforce the provisions of state and local laws. 
(7)  The fire and rescue services department is authorized to designate members of the department to serve as arson investigators for the town pursuant to A.R.S. § 41-1822. 
(8)  The town prosecutor department is authorized to prosecute all criminal cases arising from violations of this Code and state law over which the municipal court has jurisdiction and those civil cases in which the state elects to file a notice of appearance. 
(Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2525 , § I, 3-5-15; Ord. No. 2654 , § I, 4-5-18) 
Secs. 2-134-2-335. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROCUREMENT[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Street financing policy, § 10-4; business licenses, § 14-36 et seq.; taxation, ch. 58. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-336. - Solicitation transparency policy. 
(a)  Generally. Beginning on the date and time a solicitation is published, potential or actual proposers (including without limitation their employees, agents, representatives, partners, subcontractors, consultants, or attorneys) shall only discuss matters associated with the solicitation with the town's designated procurement officer identified in the solicitation and shall not discuss any matter associated with the solicitation with the mayor, any member of the town council, or any town employee unless at a public meeting, posted as required by law, until the resulting contract is awarded or all offers or responses are rejected and the solicitation is cancelled without any announcement by the designated procurement officer of the town's intent to reissue the same or a similar solicitation. 
(b)  Failure to follow solicitation transparency policy. Any violation of the solicitation transparency policy by a proposer shall result in the disqualification of the proposer from the solicitation. 
(Ord. No. 2639 , § I, 1-11-18) 
Secs. 2-337-2-355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1924, § I, adopted March 20, 2007, amended §§ 2-356-2-364 of Div. 2 to read as herein set out. Formerly §§ 2-356-2-364, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1984, §§ 3-8-4, 3-8-5; Ord. No. 1288, § I, adopted July 11, 2000; Ord. No. 1713, § I, adopted March 21, 2006. 

Sec. 2-356. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings set forth in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bid: An offer to sell supplies or services to the town in response to an invitation for bids. 
    Bid mistake: A mistake contained in a bid which is clerical or mathematical in nature. 
    Bidder list: The list of vendors from whom supplies or services may be solicited. 
    Blanket purchase order : A purchase order issued for one fiscal year to provide authorization for one vendor to supply a specific type of supplies or services. 
    Change order: A contract or purchase order amendment that authorizes a change in the scope, quantities, items, time for performance and/or pricing, etc. of a previously issued contract or purchase order. 
    Competition impractical: Procurement when the supplies or services are such that compliance with the requirements of section 2-360 or section 2-361 are impractical, unnecessary or contrary to the public interest. 
    Concessionaire agreement: An agreement whereby the town grants the right to provide a service or sell products on town property in return for compensation. 
    Construction: The process of building, altering, improving or demolishing any public structure or building, or other public improvements of any kind. It does not include the operation, maintenance or repair of existing structures, buildings, or real property. 
    Contract: A written agreement with the town for the procurement of supplies or services. The term includes supplemental agreements with respect to any such written agreement but does not include leases for real property. 
    Contract amendment: Any written alteration of any contract accomplished by mutual action of the parties to the contract, including language changes, change orders or renewals. 
    Contract renewal: A contract amendment that extends a contract based on a previously specified time period. 
    Contractor: Any person having a contract with the town. 
    Cooperative purchase contract: A contract previously bid through a competitive process by another governmental entity or by a purchasing cooperative, including purchases from the state bid list. 
    Days shall mean weekdays, unless otherwise indicated, and does not include holidays, Saturdays, or Sundays, except as provided in section 1-2. 
    Emergency purchase: Procurement when supplies, or services are needed for a situation where time is of the essence to provide for the health, safety or welfare of the public. 
    Facility relocation agreement: An agreement between the town and a utility, telecommunications or cable company where the utility, telecommunications or cable company is required to relocate its facilities as required to complete an approved capital improvement project. 
    Formal procurement: The purchase procedure described in section 2-360. 
    Independent contractors: An entity or a person not employed by the town that provides services to the town pursuant to an independent contractor contract and that meets the requirements established by the Internal Revenue Service for such designation. 
    Informal procurement: Procedures used for procurement when the formal purchase procedure is not required. 
    Intergovernmental agreement: An agreement with another public agency pursuant to A.R.S. § 11-951 et seq. 
    Invitation for bid (IFB): All documents, including those attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting bids where price is the sole determining factor. 
    Procurement: The purchasing, renting, leasing, or otherwise obtaining of any supply, or service. The term includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply or service, including description of requirements, selection and solicitations or sources, preparation and award of a contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
    Procurement officer: The purchasing officer, a contract specialist or a purchasing specialist. 
    Professional services: The services of lawyers, certified public accountants, auditors, consultants, appraisers, engineers, architects, landscape architects, assayers, geologists, land surveyors and similar occupations involving specialized knowledge, labor or skill predominantly involving mental or intellectual rather than physical or manual skills. Questions regarding whether a service is a professional service shall be referred to the purchasing officer. 
    Proposal: An offer to sell services or supplies or a combination of services and supplies to the town in response to a request for proposals. 
    Proposer: An entity or person who responds to either a request for proposals or a request for qualifications. 
    Purchase order: A written authorization from the town to acquire goods or services, authorizing a vendor to deliver to the town at a price, quantity, quality level, delivery date and other terms set forth in the purchase order. If no written contract is required pursuant to section 2-358(i), the purchase order becomes the contract. 
    Purchasing officer: The individual designated by the town manager to hold the primary purchasing authority for the town. 
    Request for proposals (RFP): All documents, including those attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting proposals. 
    Request for qualifications (RFQ): All documents, including those attached or incorporated by a reference, utilized for soliciting statements of qualifications. 
    Responsible bidder or proposer: A bidder or proposer who has the capability to perform fully the contract requirements and the reliability which will assure performance. 
    Service: The furnishing of labor, time or effort by a contractor not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than reports which are merely incidental to the required performance. This term does not include employment agreements or professional services. 
    Sole source vendor: A vendor approved in writing by the purchasing [officer] pursuant to subsection 2-357(b)(3). 
    Solicitation: An invitation for bid (IFB), request for proposals (RFP) or request for qualifications (RFQ) issued by the town. 
    Specification: Any description of the physical or functional characteristics or nature of a supply or service. The term may include a description of any requirement for inspection, testing, or preparing a supply or service for delivery. 
    State bid list: The compilation of competitive contracts awarded, issued and maintained by the State of Arizona. 
    State's vendor list: The list of vendors offering supplies or services that is maintained by the State of Arizona. 
    Submittal: A statement of qualifications submitted to the town in response to a request for qualifications. 
    Supplies: All personal property. 
    Using or requesting department: Any department of the town using or requesting supplies or services. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16; Ord. No. 2639 , § I, 1-11-18) 
Sec. 2-357. - Applicability. 
(a)  Generally. This division applies to all expenditures of public funds regardless of source or whether the purchase was made directly or indirectly by the town, including purchases using state and federal assistance monies, except that nothing in this division shall prevent the town from complying with terms and conditions of any grant, gift, bequest, or applicable regulatory guideline. This division also applies to concessionaire agreements entered into pursuant to section 2-367 and to facility relocation agreements. 
(b)  Exceptions. The following procurements are exempt from the bidding requirements of this division to the extent set forth below. 
(1)  Construction contracts unless the construction contract is exempt from the bidding requirements of A.R.S. § 34-201. 
(2)  Cooperative purchase contracts where the purchasing officer has determined in writing that a separate bidding process is not likely to result in a lower price for such supplies or services. 
(3)  Sole source vendor contracts where the using department has established to the satisfaction of the purchasing officer that the vendor is the only known supplier of a supply or service on the terms and conditions required by the using department. 
(4)  Professional services contracts. 
(5)  Intergovernmental agreements. 
(6)  Facility relocation agreements. 
(7)  Emergency purchases where the purchasing officer makes a determination that an emergency purchase is necessary and the requesting department has filed a purchase requisition marked "emergency" with the purchasing officer no later than noon the next regular town business day or after the emergency has been stabilized containing a complete written explanation and signed by the department director. 
(8)  Competition impractical purchases where the purchasing officer has determined in writing that the purchase meets the definition for a competition impractical procurement. 
(c)  Authority of purchasing officer to act in the best interest of the town. Nothing in subsection (b) shall preclude the town from soliciting bids or proposals for the procurements listed in subsection (b) if the purchasing officer or council deems it to be in the best interest of the town to do so. 
(d)  Contracts and appropriations recommended by the community services committee. Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, all contracts and appropriations recommended by the community services committee shall require approval by the council, regardless of the contract amount. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2426, § I, 5-2-13; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Sec. 2-358. - General purchasing requirements. 
(a)  Approved standard contract forms. The town attorney shall prepare all standard contract forms. The town's standard contract forms shall be used whenever possible and practical. Any revisions to the terms of standard contracts shall be first approved by the town attorney. 
(b)  Failure to follow purchasing procedures. No town employee shall order the purchase of supplies or services or make contracts on behalf of the town other than through the procedures set forth in this division and the town shall not be bound by any contract made in violation of this division. 
    Repeated violations of this article may be subject to disciplinary action. 
(c)  Contracts. For purposes of determining whether a procurement may be made through an informal procurement or through a formal purchase procedure, the value of the contract shall be based on a fiscal year. 
(d)  Purchase of multiple items. Purchases of multiple items shall not be segregated for the purpose of avoiding the requirements of this article. 
(e)  Blanket purchase orders. Individual purchases pursuant to a blanket purchase order shall be supported by receipts, invoices or other documents required by the purchasing officer. 
(f)  Independent contractors. No contract with an independent contractor shall be entered into until the purchasing officer has determined in writing that the criteria for independent contractors has been met. 
(g)  Grants. No grant application shall be submitted without approval of the council. No grant shall be accepted without approval of the council. The council may, at its discretion, approve a grant application and acceptance of the grant concurrently, provided however, that if the terms of the grant established at the time of application and the final grant award are not substantially the same, the acceptance of the grant award shall require separate approval of the council. 
(h)  Written contracts. All contracts of the town shall be in writing. 
(i)  Purchase order. All purchases over $10,000.00 require a purchase order. All services must be procured with a purchase order unless authorized by the procurement officer. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Sec. 2-359. - Purchasing authority. 
(a)  The town manager shall designate the purchasing officer of the town. The purchasing officer may delegate the powers and duties set forth in this section. The purchasing officer shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To procure and contract for supplies and services needed by any using department, in accordance with purchasing procedures as set forth in this division. 
(2)  To adopt rules and regulations for the internal management of procurements in accordance with this division. 
(3)  To designate brand names which the town uses on a regular basis, so long as such designation is for the purpose of maintaining compatibility of like supplies and the efficiencies associated with use of compatible supplies. 
(4)  To supervise the inspection or testing of deliveries of supplies or services to determine their conformance with specifications. 
(5)  To cooperate with using departments in the production of written standards and specifications for supplies and services. 
(6)  To establish and maintain the town's bidder list, or designate that the state's vendor list shall be used as the town's bidder list. 
(7)  To procure materials, supplies and services as set forth in an intergovernmental agreement, even if the procedures set forth therein differ from the procedures set forth in this division. 
(8)  To make a determination that a cooperative purchase contract is not likely to result in a lower price for such supplies or services. 
(9)  To approve facility relocation agreements. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Sec. 2-360. - Formal purchase procedure. 
(a)  Procurement of supplies and services when the estimated total annual value will exceed $100,000.00 shall be made using either written requests for proposals (RFP), requests for qualifications (RFQ) or invitations for bids (IFB), except as otherwise provided in this division. The using department's director, with the approval of the purchasing officer, shall determine which procurement method (RFP, IFB or RFQ) will be most practical and advantageous to the town for the procurement of supplies or services. 
(b)  General: 
(1)  Except as provided in subsection (2), notice of an IFB, RFP or RFQ shall include a description of the supplies or services, shall state where the IFB, RFP or RFQ forms and specifications may be obtained, the deadline for submitting a bid, proposal, or submittal, and the location for opening the bids, proposals or submittals. The notice of an IFB, RFP or RFQ shall be published pursuant to procedures set forth in A.R.S. § 39-204. Bids, proposals and submittals shall also be solicited from all prospective suppliers whose names are on the town's bidder list relevant to the scope of work. 
(2)  If a request for proposals has been issued pursuant to subsection (d)(1) below, notice of an RFP need only be given to proposers that are determined to have the qualifications to perform the required services and/or provide the required supplies. 
(3)  The purchasing officer or using department director shall have authority to require that a bid or proposal guarantee be submitted with any and all bids or proposals, and performance bonds and payment bonds be submitted prior to execution of any contract. 
(4)  Late bids, proposals or submittals shall be rejected and returned unopened to the bidder or proposer. 
(5)  The due date and time for bids, proposals or submittals may be extended by the purchasing officer after the published due date if the purchasing officer determines it is in the best interest of the town. 
(6)  The IFB, RFP or RFQ may be delayed or cancelled by the purchasing officer if the purchasing officer determines it is in the best interest of the town. 
(7)  If the procurement officer anticipates that a multiple award will be made, and it is in the best interest of the town to do so, the IFB, RFP or RFQ will include a notification of the intent of the town to make such an award, in whole or in part by line item or group of items, and the criteria upon which such an award will be based. A multiple award will be limited to the least number of vendors necessary to meet the requirements of the using town department or departments. 
(8)  The council shall have the authority, in its discretion, to refuse an award to any bidder or proposer who is in default on the payment of taxes, licenses or other moneys due the town at the time set for opening the bid or proposal. All bidders and proposers must be in compliance, at the time set for opening the bid, proposal or submittal, with all applicable state licensing laws, rules and regulations. A statement shall be included in responses to IFBs, RFPs and RFQs with a value greater than $50,000.00 that the bidder or proposer is in compliance with this paragraph. 
(9)  Awards greater than $100,000.00 require the approval of the council. The council may reject any and all bids or proposals at its sole discretion. The council's decision is final. 
(10)  No contract or procurement shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. Examples would include separate purchases which collectively would be subject to the requirements as specified in sections 2-360(a), 2-360(b)(7) and 2-361(a). 
(11)  Annual contracts for supplies purchased in large quantities may be awarded with delivery and payment for such supplies to be made during the term of the contract. 
(12)  If two or more bids received pursuant to an IFB are for the same total amount or unit price, quality and services being equal, and if the public interest will not permit the delay of re-advertising for bids, the council shall determine the successful bidder by lot. 
(13)  Capital lease purchase or contract purchase agreements shall have their value estimated as the cumulative total value of the contract expense to the town. Operating leases shall be valued at the cumulative total of lease payments for the anticipated rental period or for one year from the start of the lease for long-term items, whichever is less. 
(14)  A contract for professional services shall not be awarded to a person or firm who participates in the preparation or evaluation of a RFP or RFQ for that contract. 
(15)  Formal purchase procedures may be waived with approval of the council. 
(16)  A non-disclosure statement in a form provided by the purchasing officer shall be signed by employees who review the contents of a proposal, submittal or bid or participate in formal discussions with responsive proposers. The non-disclosure statement shall be maintained as part of the RFP, RFQ or IFB file. 
(c)  Invitation for bids (IFB): 
(1)  An IFB shall be issued and shall include a purchase description and all contractual specifications, terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. 
(2)  Bids shall be opened publicly at the time and place designated in the IFB. The amount of each bid, and such other relevant information as may be specified by the purchasing officer or using department's director, together with the name of each bidder shall be recorded. This record shall be open to public inspection after the bid opening. Trade secrets or other proprietary data designated in the bid as such shall remain confidential unless otherwise required by the public records law. 
(3)  After bid opening, no changes to bid prices or other provisions of bids or withdrawal of bids which are prejudicial to the interest of the town or fair competition shall be permitted. All decisions to permit the correction of a bid mistake, to permit withdrawal of any bid based on a bid mistake or, to cancel an award based on a bid mistake after bid opening shall be supported by a written determination made by the purchasing officer. 
(4)  The contract shall be awarded to the lowest responsible and responsive bidder whose bid conforms in all material respects to the requirements and criteria set forth in the IFB. In making the determination of the lowest responsible and responsive bidder, the council may consider the following: 
a.  The ability, capacity and experience of the bidder, its employees and subcontractors to perform the contract. 
b.  Whether the bidder can perform the contract promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
c.  The quality of performance of previous contracts. 
d.  The sufficiency of the financial resources of the bidder to perform the contract. 
e.  The quality and adaptability of the materials, supplies or services to the particular use required. 
(5)  If an award is not made to the lowest bidder, a statement of the reason for not awarding to the lowest bidder shall be given in writing and be placed in the contract file. 
(d)  Request for proposals (RFP) and request for qualifications (RFQ): 
(1)  Proposals shall be solicited through an RFP. Submittals shall be solicited through an RFQ. At the discretion of the purchasing officer or requesting department, an RFQ may be issued prior to issuance of an RFP. Alternatively, an RFQ may provide for a qualifications-based selection process without a subsequent RFP. RFPs and RFQs shall be published pursuant to A.R.S. § 39-204. RFPs and RFQs shall require the proposer to disclose any actual or potential conflicts of interest the proposer may have in performing the required services. 
(2)  Proposals and submittals shall be opened publicly at the time and place designated in the RFP or RFQ. The name of each proposer shall be publicly read and recorded. Trade secrets or other proprietary data designated in the proposal as such shall remain confidential, unless otherwise required by the public records law. 
(3)  Discussion may be conducted with responsive proposers who submit proposals determined to be reasonably susceptible to being selected for award for the purpose of clarification to assure full understanding of, and responsiveness to, the solicitation requirements. Proposers shall be accorded fair treatment with respect to any opportunity for discussion and revision of proposals and such revisions may be permitted after submissions and before award for the purpose of obtaining best and final offers. In conducting discussions, there shall be no disclosure of any information derived from proposals submitted by competing proposers during the negotiation process. Where permitted in the RFQ or SOQ and if the purchasing officer believes it would be in the best interest of the town to require proposers who are determined to be reasonably susceptible to being selected for award of a contract, the purchasing officer may require such proposers to submit their best and final offers, whether or not the scope has been revised. 
(4)  For an RFP, the award shall be made to the responsible and responsive proposer whose proposal is determined, in writing, to be the most advantageous to the town and best meets the overall needs of the town taking into consideration the evaluation of factors set forth in the request for proposals and this subsection (4). The town is not bound to award to the lowest cost (priced) RFP. No other factors or criteria may be used in the evaluation other than as set forth in the request for proposals or in this subsection (d). In addition to the criteria set forth in the request for proposals, the following criteria may be considered: 
a.  Price. 
b.  The ability, capacity and experience of the proposer, its employees and subcontractors to perform the contract. 
c.  Whether the proposer can perform the contract promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference. 
d.  The quality of performance of previous contracts. 
e.  The sufficiency of the financial resources of the proposer to perform the contract. 
f.  The quality and adaptability of the materials, supplies or services to the particular use required. 
g.  The number and scope of conditions attached to the proposer's offer, and conformance of the proposer's offer to material aspects of the request for proposal. 
(5)  The contract file shall contain the basis on which the award is made. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2567, § I , 1-14-16; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16; Ord. No. 2639 , § I, 1-11-18) 
Sec. 2-361. - Informal purchase procedures. 
(a)  Purchases between $10,000.00 and $100,000.00. Procurements of supplies and services of an estimated value less than $100,000.00 but greater than $10,000.00 shall be based on at least three written quotations, unless the purchase is made pursuant to subsection 2-357(b), and provided that such purchases are approved by the purchasing officer, or the using department's director if the amount is less than $50,000.00. Such purchases do not require the approval of the council and shall be in accordance with the adopted budget of the town. Informal purchase procedures may be waived with approval of the purchasing officer. 
(1)  The purchasing officer or using department's director shall solicit by e-mail, fax, direct mail request, or by telephone, or by interview of prospective vendors. 
(2)  The purchasing officer or using department shall designate a central location for records of all awards and the responses submitted in competition thereon, and such records shall be part of the public record. 
(b)  Purchases of $10,000.00 or less. Procurements of supplies, equipment and services of a purchase price less than $10,000.00 may be made without seeking quotations, provided that such purchases are approved by the purchasing officer or the using department's director. Such purchases do not require the approval of the council and must be in accordance with the adopted budget of the town. 
(Ord. No. 1924, § I, 3-20-07; Ord. No. 1965, § I, 5-22-07; Ord. No. 2382, § I, 8-16-12; Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Sec. 2-362. - Contract change orders and renewals. 
(a)  Except as provided in paragraph (c) below, change orders that increase or decrease the contract amount may be approved and executed by the purchasing officer if the total of the original contract value and all change orders does not exceed $100,000.00, or the original contract value was $100,000.00 or more and the change order is less than $10,000.00 or ten percent of the original contract value (whichever is greater), or if the change order has no monetary value. All other change orders shall be approved by the council. 
(b)  Contracts may be renewed upon written approval of the purchasing officer if: 
(1)  The renewal contract amount does not exceed $100,000.00; or 
(2)  The renewal includes a price increase of less than ten percent; or 
(3)  The original prices remain in effect during the renewal term. The council must approve contract renewals in all other cases. 
(c)  For contracts governed by A.R.S. Title 34, all change orders over $10,000.00 or ten percent of the original contract value (whichever is greater) require council approval. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16; Ord. No. 2604 , § I, 1-26-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-362 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-362 pertained to change orders and derived from Ord. No. 1924, § I, adopted March 20, 2007; and Ord. No. 2382, § I, adopted Aug. 16, 2012. 
Sec. 2-363. - Job order contracts. 
(a)  Job orders issued pursuant to a job order (JOC) contract may be approved by the purchasing officer if the amount does not exceed $100,000.00. The council must approve job orders in all other cases. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-363 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-363 pertained to surplus supplies and equipment and derived from Ord. No. 1924, § I, adopted March 20, 2007; and Ord. No. 2382, § I, adopted Aug. 16, 2012. 
Sec. 2-364. - Surplus supplies and equipment. 
(a)  All departments and offices shall submit to the purchasing officer, at such time, and in such form as shall be prescribed, reports showing all supplies and equipment which are no longer used or which have become obsolete or worn out. The purchasing officer shall dispose of such supplies and equipment pursuant to the provisions of A.R.S. § 9-402. 
(b)  Surplus supplies may be leased or donated to persons pursuant to a written contract approved by the council, provided that the town receives adequate consideration for the surplus supplies. 
(c)  Surplus property valued at less than $25.00 may be donated to a charity approved by the purchasing officer pursuant to A.R.S. § 12-941(D). 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-364 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-364 pertained to purchasing supplies, materials and equipment from the mayor or any member of the council and derived from Ord. No. 1924, § I, adopted March 20, 2007. 
Sec. 2-365. - Purchasing supplies and services from the mayor or any member of the council. 
    Pursuant to A.R.S. § 38-503(C), the town, through its council, may purchase supplies, materials and equipment not to exceed $300.00 in cost in any single transaction and not to exceed a total of $1,000.00 annually, from the mayor or any member of the council without using competitive public bidding procedures, according to an annually adopted town policy. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-365 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-365 pertained to concessionaire agreements and derived from Ord. No. 2426, § I, adopted May 2, 2013. 
Sec. 2-366. - Purchasing supplies, materials, equipment and services from town employees. 
    The town may purchase supplies, and services not to exceed $300.00 in cost in any single transaction and not to exceed a total of $1,000.00 annually, from town employees without using competitive public bidding procedures, according to an annually adopted town policy. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-366 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-366 pertained to protests and derived from Ord. No. 2382, § I, adopted Aug. 16, 2012; and Ord. No. 2426, § I, adopted May 2, 2013. 
Sec. 2-367. - Concessionaire agreements. 
(a)  Concessionaire agreements where the estimated annual revenue to the town will not exceed $100,000.00 may be approved by the purchasing officer without an invitation for bids or a request for proposals. Nothing in this section shall preclude the purchasing officer from soliciting bids or proposals if he deems it to be in the best interest of the town to do so. 
(b)  All other concessionaire agreements shall be made pursuant to an invitation for bids or a request for proposals and require approval of the council. The council may waive the requirement to obtain bids or proposals. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2593 , § I, adopted Sep. 29, 2016, amended § 2-367 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 2-367 pertained to fingerprinting of prospective contractors and employees of contractors and derived from Ord. No. 940, § 1, adopted June 28, 1995; Ord. No. 1288, § I, adopted July 11, 2000; Ord. No. 2382, § I, adopted Aug. 16, 2012; and Ord. No. 2426, § I, adopted May 2, 2013. 
Sec. 2-368. - Protests. 
(a)  An unsuccessful proposer or bidder may protest a solicitation by filing a protest in writing to the purchasing officer not less than three days before the closing date and time of the solicitation. An unsuccessful proposer or bidder may protest a contract award by filing a protest in writing with the purchasing office not less than three days after issuance of a notice of apparent low responsive and responsible bidder, or a notice of intent to award. The protest shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the protester; 
(2)  The signature of the protester or its authorized representative; 
(3)  A detailed statement of the legal and factual grounds of the protest, including copies of relevant documents. 
(b)  The purchasing officer shall evaluate and determine protests in connection with a solicitation or an award of a contract involving an amount less than $100,000.00. The purchasing officer shall issue a written response no later than ten days from the date of receipt of the protest. The determination of the purchasing officer may be appealed in writing to the town finance director no later than five days from receipt of the purchasing officer's determination. The finance director shall respond to the appeal within five days from the date of receipt of the appeal. The finance director's decision shall be final. 
(c)  If the protest is in connection with a solicitation or award of a contract involving $100,000.00 or more, it may be appealed to the town council. The purchasing officer shall issue a written recommendation to the council after the protest has been filed. The recommendation shall contain the basis for the recommendation. The council shall issue a final decision on the protest at a public meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Sec. 2-369. - Fingerprinting of prospective contractors and employees of contractors. 
    Prior to entering into a contract for services in an area designated as sensitive by the town manager, the town shall require that a contractor and employees of a contractor shall provide to the police chief or his designee, fingerprint identification. The police chief or his designee shall, pursuant to A.R.S. § 41-1750 and Public Law 92-184 Section 902, forward those fingerprints accompanied by appropriate fees to the State Department of Public Safety and the Federal Bureau of Investigation for the purpose of seeking criminal history information on such contractor and employees of such contractor. Information obtained shall be used only for the purpose of evaluating the fitness of prospective contractors and their employees to provide services to the town and shall otherwise remain confidential. 
(Ord. No. 2593 , § I, 9-29-16) 
Secs. 2-370-2-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PAYMENTS BY TOWN 

Sec. 2-381. - Warrant-Drawing. 
(a)  When an allowable bill is presented for payment, a warrant shall be drawn on the treasury of the town, signed by the mayor and countersigned by the treasurer, which warrant shall be delivered to the party in his favor when the warrant is drawn. All warrants shall be payable to the order of the person entitled to such warrant, and shall be endorsed by him before presentation to the treasurer. Such warrants may be presented by the assignee, executor or administrator of the estate of the person to whom the same is drawn. 
(b)  No claim, charge, cost or expenditure shall be paid by the treasurer unless signed by the mayor and clerk, as provided in this section. 
(Code 1984, § 3-9-3) 
Sec. 2-382. - Same-Form. 
    All warrants shall specify the liability for which they are drawn, when the same occurred, and shall be paid in the order of presentation. If the funds upon which the warrant is drawn are insufficient to pay the same, the warrant shall be registered by the treasurer, and thereafter paid in the order of its presentation when such funds shall become sufficient. The town treasurer shall adopt a suitable form of warrant in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1984, § 3-9-4) 
State Law reference- Maximum rate of interest on warrants, A.R.S. § 9-249. 
Secs. 2-383-2-385. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ADMINISTRATIVE CLAIMS[8] 

Footnotes:
