Editor's note- Ord. No. 2408, § I, adopted Dec. 6, 2012, repealed Div. 2, §§ 62-126-62-134, which pertained to registration and derived from §§ 12-2-2(A)-(D) and 12-2-4-12-2-8 of the 1984 Code. 

Secs. 62-126-62-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOTORIZED PLAY VEHICLES AND MOTORIZED SKATEBOARDS 

Sec. 62-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Should any word, term or phrase conflict with a definition in A.R.S. Title 28, the definitions in Title 28 shall apply. 
    Moped means as defined under A.R.S., Title 28. 
    Motor driven cycle means as defined under A.R.S., Title 28. 
    Motorcycle means as defined under A.R.S., Title 28. 
    Motorized play vehicle, for the purpose of this article, means a moped, motor driven cycle, motorcycle, or motorized quadricycle unless otherwise specified in this article. Motorized play vehicle does not include a motorized wheelchair. 
    Motorized skateboard means a self-propelled device which has a motor, a deck on which a person may ride and at least two wheels in contact with the ground unless otherwise defined in A.R.S., Title 28. 
    Motorized play vehicle means as defined under section 62-141. 
    Motorized quadricycle means as defined under A.R.S., Title 28. 
    Motorized skateboard means as defined in section 62-141. 
    Operator means a person who operates or is in actual physical control of a device governed by this article. 
    Owner means a person who holds the legal title to a device governed by this article, or any person who is a lessee, conditional vendee or mortgagor of said device with a right to immediate possession. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 2703, § I, 3-7-19 ) 
Sec. 62-142. - Applicability of traffic laws; registration; licenses. 
(a)  All traffic laws shall apply to persons riding motorized play vehicles and motorized skateboards. Every person operating a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the rules applicable to vehicles, including, but not limited to, the laws under A.R.S., Title 28, and the traffic regulations of the town, unless otherwise stated in said rules and laws and except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. 
(b)  Subject to subsection (a), this section shall not be construed to require the registration of motorized play vehicles or motorized skateboards. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person operating a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard to fail to obey the instructions of official traffic-control signals, signs, and other traffic direction devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(d)  The town shall have the authority to issue a civil citation to any person deemed in violation of this section. For the purpose of subsection (d), each unauthorized motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall be treated as a separate violation and each day of violation shall be a separate violation upon failure to remove or diligently pursue the removal of the motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 2703, § I, 3-7-19 ) 
Sec. 62-143. - Responsibility of parents, guardians, and custodians. 
    No person shall, if a parent, guardian, or custodian of a child, authorize or knowingly permit any child to violate this article. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98) 
Sec. 62-144. - Prohibited operation. 
    No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard: 
(a)  On any sidewalk, except for use in crossing such sidewalk by the most direct route to gain access to any public or private road or driveway. 
(b)  In any town parking structure or town park, except for use on public roadways within such park. 
(c)  On any public property that has been posted or designated by the owner of such property as an area prohibiting "skateboards." 
(d)  On any public roadway consisting of a total of four or more marked traffic lanes, or having an established speed limit of greater than 25 miles per hour. 
(e)  On any private property of another, or any public property which is not held open to the public for vehicle use, without the written permission of the owner, the person entitled to immediate possession of the property, or the authorized agent of either. 
(f)  Within any path or lane that is designated as a bicycle lane or path by state or local authorities. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 1255, § I, 3-28-00) 
Sec. 62-145. - General operating restrictions. 
(a)  No child under the age of 13 shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard in excess of the posted speed limit or at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the circumstances then existing. 
(c)  The operator of a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard, approaching a sidewalk, bicycle path, bicycle lane, or multiuse path in order to cross such, shall yield the right-of-way to all other users. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  No operator of a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall allow passengers when the motorized skateboard is in operation or motion. 
(f)  No person operating or riding upon a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall attach themselves or the motorized skateboard in any manner to any other vehicle. 
(g)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard while carrying any package, bundle or article which prevents the operator from keeping both hands upon the steering mechanism at all times. 
(h)  No person, other than the owner, shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard without the written permission of the owner. 
(i)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard that has been structurally altered from the original manufacturer's design, unless such structural alteration reduces the noise level emitted from the motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard below the noise level emitted by the original manufacturer's design. 
(j)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard in a crosswalk. 
(k)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard in such a manner that it emits any noise that exceeds eighty decibels, using the measurement criteria set forth in section 42-61(d) and measured at a distance of 35 feet from the motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 1255, § I, 3-28-00; Ord. No. 1569, § I, 6-8-04) 
Sec. 62-146. - Operating restrictions on roadway. 
(a)  A person operating a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard on a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic, at the time and place and under the then existing conditions, shall ride as close as practicable to the right hand curb, edge of the roadway or edge of a designated bicycle path or lane except under the following conditions and when the movement can be made in safety: 
(1)  If overtaking and passing a vehicle proceeding in the same direction. 
(2)  If preparing for a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway. 
(3)  If reasonably necessary to avoid hazardous conditions ahead in the roadway. 
(4)  If the lane in which the person is operating the motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard is too narrow for a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard and a bicycle or another vehicle to travel safely side by side within the lane. 
(b)  No operator of a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall transport extra fuel in a separate container or alter the fuel reservoir from the original manufacturer's design. This includes the prohibition of physically attaching fuel packs or containers to the operator's person. 
(c)  Persons operating motorized play vehicles or motorized skateboards on the roadway shall not ride more than two abreast. 
(d)  No motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall be operated on a roadway between sunset or 8:00 p.m., whichever is earliest, and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 1255, § I, 3-28-00; Ord. No. 1569, § I, 6-8-04) 
Sec. 62-147. - Required safety equipment. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard unless it is equipped with a brake which enables the operator to make a braked wheel(s) skid on pavement. 
(b)  Any operator of a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard under the age of 18 years being operated on a roadway shall at all times wear a protective helmet on his or her head in an appropriate and safely secured manner. The helmet shall meet minimum standards of testing and safety inspected by the bicycle industry. 
(c)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard without wearing footwear. The footwear must have a sole and completely cover the feet and toes. 
(d)  The operator of a motorized play vehicle or motorized skateboard shall wear, at all times, protective glasses or goggles or a transparent face shield of a type approved for motorcycle or motor-driven cycle use. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 2408, § I, 12-6-12) 
Sec. 62-148. - Violations. 
    Violations of this article are civil traffic violations and shall be prosecuted as provided in section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1079, § I, 1-6-98) 
Chapter 66 - UTILITIES OPERATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cable communications, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Municipal utilities, A.R.S. § 9-511 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 66-1. - Applicability of article; general provisions. 
(a)  This chapter governs the operation of utility services provided by the town. The provisions of this article shall be applicable generally to all utility services provided by the town. Where provisions of this article conflict with specific provisions, such specific provisions shall apply. 
(b)  Utility service shall mean potable water service, irrigation service, reclaimed water service, sewer service, effluent delivery and solid waste service provided by the town. 
(c)  The services provided for under this chapter are limited to the town's equipment ability and capacity. This chapter shall not create any liability nor impose any affirmative duty upon the town, its officers or employees. Nothing in this chapter shall mandate the town to secure new sources of revenue or allocate existing funds in any particular manner. 
(d)  Enforcement rights granted to the town under this chapter are cumulative and in addition to any other remedy available to the town at law or equity. 
Sec. 66-2. - Delegation of authority for administration and enforcement of chapter. 
    The director of public works is delegated the authority to exercise the powers and perform the duties set forth in this chapter and to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. The director of public works may designate other employees to exercise such powers and perform such duties as he deems appropriate. 
Sec. 66-3. - Agreement for utility service. 
(a)  Requests for service. The act of requesting or receiving utility service from the town constitutes an agreement by the customer to comply with all the terms and conditions related thereto which are imposed by the town. 
(b)  Customers. As a condition of initiating, continuing or reestablishing utility service, the town may require the customer to execute an agreement for utility service in a form provided by the town. 
(c)  Telephone or other activation. Finance director may permit utility service agreement to be activated by telephone, or Internet. 
(d)  Town may reject any application. The town may reject any application for utility service for any good and sufficient reason including, but not limited to, the failure to meet any condition of rendering service specified in section 66-6 (conditions of receipt of utility service). 
(Ord. No. 1818, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Sec. 66-4. - When utility service is required; discontinuation of services. 
(a)  Customers shall accept all gilbert utility services that are available for residential and non-residential structures upon the issuance of a certificate of occupancy except that non-residential structures shall have the option to select alternative solid waste collection services. 
(b)  During the initial construction period on residential or non-residential structures, water and wastewater services shall be charged from the time a water meter is installed, except that wastewater services shall not be charged for any property that is not connected to the gilbert sewer system, provided such structure is legally connected to a sanitary cesspool in good working order. 
(c)  Residential structures that are receiving solid waste services in accordance with subsection (a) above shall be billed from the time a certificate of occupancy is issued for the structure, unless otherwise provided in this section. 
(d)  Residential structures that are required to receive single family residential solid waste service and that have been identified by the director of public works as non-occupied model homes shall be exempt from solid waste collection services, provided the owner applies for and receives approval for such exemption by Gilbert. 
(e)  No customer may suspend or discontinue utility services unless all utility services provided pursuant to subsection (a) are discontinued by such customer and such discontinuance is verified by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2313, § I, adopted Dec. 9, 2010, renumbered the former §§ 66-4-66-9 as §§ 66-5-66-10, and added a new § 66-4 as set out herein. The historical notation has been retained with the amended provisions for reference purposes. 
Sec. 66-5. - Customer responsibilities. 
(a)  Timely payment for services. Each customer shall be responsible for timely payment for utility services provided under the customer's name or to the customer's property until the utility service is duly terminated or discontinued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Maintenance of customer facilities. Each customer shall be responsible for maintaining all facilities on the customer's side of the point of delivery in a safe and efficient manner and in accordance with any applicable law, rule, regulation or order. 
(c)  Safeguarding town property. Each customer shall be responsible for safeguarding all town property installed in or on the customer's premises for the purpose of providing utility services. 
(d)  Prevention of loss or damage. Each customer shall exercise all reasonable care to prevent loss or damage to town property, excluding ordinary wear and tear. The customer shall be responsible for loss of or damage to utility property on the customer's premises arising from neglect, carelessness, or misuse and shall reimburse the utility for the cost of necessary repairs or replacements. 
(e)  Payment for equipment damage. Each customer shall be responsible for payment for any equipment damage resulting from unauthorized breaking of seals, interfering, tampering or bypassing the measurement device used by the town to measure the utility service being provided. 
(f)  Notification by property owners of nonservice of properties. Persons who lease, rent or otherwise permit the occupancy of their real property within the town or which are eligible to receive utility service from the town shall notify the town if the property is not to be provided utility service by the town. Property owners who fail to notify the town shall be jointly and severally liable for any utility service requested or received by the tenant, lessee or other occupant of their property and authorizes the town to enforce liens against their real property. 
(g)  Provision of equipment for service. Each customer shall be responsible for providing, without cost to the town, all utility equipment, lines, meters, and appurtenant facilities necessary for the town to provide proper utility service to the customer and to provide title to such facilities in a manner deemed acceptable to the town. 
(h)  Provision of access for service or inspection. Each customer shall be responsible for providing safe ingress and egress to, and cooperating with, the town's employees, representatives and agents for the purpose of accessing facilities related to the provision of utility service and to perform inspections related to the provision of utility service and shall maintain all easements and rights-of-way of the town free and clear of obstructions and hazardous conditions. 
(i)  Compliance with applicable laws. Each customer shall comply with all applicable provisions of this chapter and any other law, rule, regulation or order governing the provision or receipt of utility service. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Sec. 66-6. - Conditions of receipt of utility service. 
(a)  No utility service shall be initiated, continued or reestablished unless all of the following are met: 
(1)  The town offers and determines it is capable of providing the utility service under an established rate. 
(2)  Providing the utility service would not involve excessive cost to the town. 
(3)  Providing the utility service would not adversely affect the service to existing customers. 
(4)  The customer has executed a service agreement for the utility service in a form provided by the town. 
(5)  All deposits, fees and other charges applicable to the utility service have been paid. 
(6)  All bills rendered for utility service provided to the customer and any required deposits have been paid. 
(7)  All extensions to the town's system necessary to provide service to the customer have been constructed and accepted by the town, without cost to the town. 
(8)  All improvements at the service location necessary to enable the town to provide the utility service have been completed, without cost to the town. 
(9)  Adequate easements and rights-of-way, satisfactory to the town, have been granted to the town to ensure the town can provide proper utility service to the service location. 
(10)  The dwelling or residence, if intended for human habitation, is equipped with a water closet in good working order, properly connected to a sanitary sewer or where such sanitary sewer is not available, connected to a sanitary cesspool in good working order. 
(11)  The customer and the service location is in compliance with all provisions of this Code and all rules, regulations and procedures adopted thereunder. 
(12)  If a customer with more than one account seeks to open a new account, the customer must be current on all its existing utility accounts before service can be initiated for the new account. 
(b)  The initiation, continuation or reestablishment of utility service shall not constitute a determination by the town that the conditions for service set forth in subsection (a) of this section have been met; nor does it preclude the town from pursuing any remedy available to the town arising from the consumer's failure to satisfy the condition including, but not limited to, termination of utility service with or without notice. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Sec. 66-7. - Utility equipment. 
(a)  All utility equipment including, but not limited to, water mains, sewer mains, service pipes, meters, trash containers and appurtenant equipment supplied or maintained by the public works department or on the town's side of the point of delivery is vested in the town. In no case shall the owner of any premises have the right to claim any right, title or interest therein except where otherwise provided in this chapter or by written contract with the town. The owner of the premises shall provide town documentation evidencing the town's title to the facilities in a form acceptable to the town, if so requested by the town. 
(b)  No person, without the prior consent of the director of public works, shall use, connect to or otherwise manipulate the town's utility equipment. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Sec. 66-8. - Prohibited acts; tampering; obstruction; discontinuation of service. 
(a)  Any person who interferes with the officers or agents of the town in the discharge of their duties under this chapter, or who digs up or causes to be dug up any sidewalk, street or alley for the purpose of connecting with the potable water, irrigation, effluent delivery, or sewer systems of the town without first obtaining a permit from the building official to do so, or who, having such a permit, digs up or causes to be dug up any portion of any sidewalk, street or alley for the purpose of connecting with the potable water, irrigation, effluent delivery or sewer systems and fails to replace the sidewalk, street or alley in its original condition, or who violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a class one misdemeanor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally, knowingly or recklessly to do any of the following: 
(1)  Tamper, as that term is defined in A.R.S. § 13-3724(e), with property that is owned or used by the town to provide utility service. 
(2)  Make a connection or reconnection with property that is owned or used by the town to provide utility service without the authorization or consent of the town. 
(3)  Prevent a utility meter or other device that is used to determine the charge for utility services from accurately performing its measuring function. 
(4)  Divert or cause to be diverted utility services by any means or use, receive or otherwise divert utility services without the authorization of the town if the customer or person knows or has reason to know of the unlawful diversion, tampering or connection. 
(c)  There is a rebuttable presumption that the customer in whose name the service is provided or person who receives such service intentionally violated this section if any of the following occurs: 
(1)  An instrument, apparatus or device that was installed to obtain utility service without paying the full charge is found attached to the meter or other device that is used to provide the utility service on the premises controlled by the customer or by the person who uses or receives the utility service; or 
(2)  A meter was altered, tampered with or bypassed resulting in an inaccurate measurement of utility services; or 
(3)  The customer, person or owner is an occupant of the premises, or has an access to the system for delivery of the service to the premises and receives a benefit from tampered or bypassed equipment. 
This presumption shifts the burden of going forward with the evidence but does not shift the burden of proof to the defendant. 
(d)  No person shall obstruct or place upon or about any utility appliance or fixture including, but not limited to, any valve, valve box, curb cock, meter box, or water gate connected with the potable water, irrigation, effluent delivery or sewer systems of the town or any object, material, debris or structure of any kind that shall prevent free access to the same at all times or in any manner tamper with or injure such appurtenances. No person shall fill up or cover over any valve or meter box. The town may physically remove, tow or otherwise relocate any obstructions to public utility facilities at the customer's, owner's or occupant's expense. 
(e)  Any person who violates subsections (b) or (d) by tampering with, obstructing or otherwise breaking, destroying or damaging a water meter, or who by-passes, disconnects or diverts water around a meter to avoid charges associated with his/her water usage shall pay: (1) a $100.00 tampering fee for each occurrence for each day the violation continues; and (2) the reasonable cost of the water used during the period the tampering or obstruction occurred. For purposes of this section, "reasonable cost" shall be calculated using either the average water usage costs billed to the customer or prior user in the three months prior to the occurrence of the tampering or obstruction, an estimate of the amount of water used by similar or comparable users or structures located elsewhere in the town, or any other credible evidence of the person's use of water during the period of such tampering. 
(f)  Any violation shall be corrected by the town and the costs incurred for such correction shall be assessed to the customer, owner or occupant for correcting such violations. All such costs shall be billed on the next water statement and become due and payable on that statement's due date unless a request for a hearing is filed with the town to dispute the charges. If service had been previously terminated pursuant to this Code, service shall remain terminated until all associated costs are paid in full. 
(g)  In addition to the penalties provided in subsection (e) above, the town may discontinue, suspend or refuse service to any consumer or other person who tampers with, obstructs the potable water, irrigation, effluent delivery or sewer systems of the town, or who otherwise willfully disregards the provisions of the utility services contract or this chapter, commits fraud or abuse. 
(h)  The town may further discontinue, suspend or refuse utility service for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  As a result of emergency repair, insufficient supply, legal process, strike, riot, fire, flood, accident or any unavoidable cause. 
(2)  An unauthorized turn-on. 
(3)  The failure of the customer or the property owner to meet any of the conditions for initiating, continuing or reestablishing service set forth in section 66-6. 
(4)  At the direction of the council. 
(i)  Before any discontinuation, supension or refusal of utility service takes effect, the town shall notify the person in whose name the service is provided in writing of the violation and the date such service shall cease. The written notification shall also provide for an opportunity to meet with the town prior to the cessation of such service. 
(j)  Any person who wishes to permanently discontinue a utility service shall provide advance notice to the town of the intended termination of the utility service. The notice shall include the customer's name, service location, account number, and the proposed termination date, and shall not be deemed given unless in writing and received by the finance manager. The finance manager may establish in writing an alternative notice procedure such as telephonic or electronic notice. If termination of the utility service would violate this chapter, the customer shall be so notified and the utility service shall not be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 1819, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Sec. 66-9. - Limitation of liability of town. 
    The town does not warrant nor guarantee its ability to provide continuous or uninterrupted utility service; nor does the town warrant or guarantee any particular level of utility service. If utility service is interrupted, discontinued, irregular or defective or fails from causes beyond the town's control or due to the ordinary negligence of its employees, servants or agents, the town shall not be liable for damages, claims or losses arising therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Sec. 66-10. - Right of entry; inspections. 
(a)  The town shall have the right to enter commercial, institutional and industrial establishments and to enter upon residential property for inspection purposes related to the provision of utility service as required by this chapter or any other law, rule, regulation or order of an entity having jurisdiction thereover and for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(b)  Provision shall be made for regular inspection of the town's facilities used in providing utility service and when required by this chapter or any other law, rule, regulation or order of an entity having jurisdiction thereover, for the inspection of premises receiving utility service for purposes related to the provision of utility service. 
(Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Note- See the editor's note to § 66-4. 
Secs. 66-11-66-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES; BILLING AND COLLECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Waiver of utility deposits and building permit, plan review, inspection and grading and drainage permit fees for school districts, § 10-1. 

Sec. 66-71. - Establishment of utility rates. 
(a)  Rates, deposits, charges, and fees, for each utility service shall be established by resolution of the council. 
(b)  Utility rates shall be established to recover at least the cost of providing each utility service, including services ancillary thereto, and to maintain adequate fund reserves for each utility to provide for reasonably expected variations in the cost of providing the utility service, as well as variations in the demand for such utility service. 
(c)  Applicable taxes, assessments, fees, or other charges imposed by any entity related to a specific utility service may be added to the bill for that utility service as a pass-through cost unless otherwise included in the service rate. The method of passing through any such cost shall be determined by the finance director by written report on file with the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 66-72. - Billing and payment for utility service. 
(a)  Bills for utility services shall be mailed on a regular schedule (in most instances monthly) and shall be due upon receipt. Each bill shall separately set forth the amount due for each utility service for which a charge is being made. 
(b)  Where the utility service is measured, the town shall bill based on the readings of the measuring device unless the town is unable to read the measuring device or has reason to believe the measuring device is inaccurate. In such instances the town shall bill based upon the customer's estimated usage utilizing generally accepted estimating techniques. The customer's bill shall indicate if the billing is based upon an estimate of usage. 
(c)  Partial payments for utility service shall be first applied to all fees and service charges for refuse collection, sewer service, irrigation service, and water service, in that order. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 66-73. - Procedure to challenge utility bills; correction of utility bills. 
(a)  All bills tendered for utility services are presumed to be correct. 
(b)  A person who believes a utility bill or any charge related to a utility service is incorrect shall: 
(1)  Submit a claim in writing to the town finance director on a form approved by the town. The dispute will be reviewed by the finance director. An adjustment or determination will be provided to the customer in writing. 
(2)  Any customer who feels aggrieved by the determination of the finance director or his designee, or by the discontinuation, suspension, or refusal of utility service may file an appeal within 15 days from receipt of the determination. The appeal must be in writing and filed with the deputy town manager appointed by the manager to oversee appeals pursuant to this article. The decision of the deputy town manager is final. 
(c)  Disputing a bill or contacting the town regarding a bill shall not relieve the customer of the obligation to make timely payment as specified in section 66-72 or preclude the town from terminating utility service or taking any other action permitted by this chapter or otherwise. 
(d)  If utility services is provided to a customer and the town fails to bill for such service, a correction will be made to the active utility account within the next billing cycle after the inaccuracy is identified, pursuant to the following terms: 
(1)  If the town determines that the customer was reasonably unaware that it was not being billed the full amount of the utilities being provided, the town shall bill the account back to the date the utility service was provided and not billed, or for a 12-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. The town will allow the customer to repay the difference over the length of time equivalent to the period for which the customer was under-billed or for a 12-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. 
(2)  If a customer knowingly receives services without paying for those services in full, the customer will be back-billed to the initial date when services were provided and not billed. 
(e)  If utility service is not provided and the town bills and collects payment for such service, a credit will be made to the utility account within the next billing cycle after the inaccuracy is identified, pursuant to the following terms: 
(1)  It is established by town records or the customer establishes that the payments were made to the town's satisfaction. 
(2)  The finance director determines that there was no meter tampering. If the account is closed, or the credit exceeds three months of utility service, the customer may request the credit be refunded after any outstanding utility bills are paid in full. 
(3)  The request for a correction to the utility account must be filed on or after January 1, 2011. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10; Ord. No. 2357, § I, 1-26-12; Ord. No. 2648 , § I, 2-15-18) 
Sec. 66-74. - Delinquent bills; termination of service. 
(a)  A utility service bill which remains unpaid 20 days from the billing date (printed on the bill) is delinquent and is subject to imposition of a fee. 
(b)  A utility service may be terminated if the bill for such utility service remains unpaid from the billing date for 45 days. Prior to termination, the customer shall be notified in writing that the utility service is subject to termination and that the bill may be discussed with the finance director or his designee. Notice may be provided on or with the regular billing to the customer or by separate notice delivered by hand or regular United States Postal Service at the service address or the most recent mailing address provided by the customer. 
(c)  The billing date shall be as set forth on the bill. 
(d)  If the consumer whose bill is delinquent is not the owner of the premises, and the town has notice of this and the address of the owner is known to the clerk, then notice shall be mailed to the owner of the premises whenever such bills remain unpaid for a period of 55 days after the billing date. The town's failure to provide notice or the owner's failure to receive notice shall not affect the town's right to terminate utility service for nonpayment. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 66-75. - Reestablishment of utility service. 
(a)  A utility service which has been terminated may not be reestablished except upon payment of all outstanding amounts owed to the town related to utility service, including all fees, service charges, and any additional deposits required to establish utility service, and any other incidental costs, expenses occasioned by the service termination. 
(b)  The finance director may establish procedures by which a delinquent bill may be brought current in not more than three months. Failure to comply with the terms and conditions so established shall be grounds for immediate termination of utility service with or without notice. 
(c)  The finance director or his designee is authorized to provide a waiver of any fee if it is determined that the customer has a utility bill history without delinquency for the prior year; provided however, that the outstanding utility bill is brought current. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05) 
Sec. 66-76. - Liens for nonpayment; foreclosure. 
(a)  Whenever a property owner has entered into an agreement with gilbert for utility service to his property, the property owner consents to a lien against the property for the amount of unpaid utility bills, together with late payment, penalty, interest and collection costs until the bill is paid in full. 
(b)  Whenever a bill for utility service remains unpaid for 90 days from the billing date, the town shall have the right to sell the real property subject to the lien, and the proceeds of such sale shall be applied to pay the charges, after deducting costs, as is the case in the foreclosure of statutory liens. The town attorney is hereby authorized and, upon the direction of the director of public works, shall institute such proceedings, in the name of the town, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters, against any property for which the utility bill has remained unpaid for 90 days after the billing date. Any number of liens on the same lot or tract of land under this section may be enforced in the same action. 
(c)  Whenever a utility bill for a utility service remains unpaid for 90 days after the billing date, the town may file with the county recorder a statement of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the town claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges for the utility served subsequent to the period covered by the bill. 
(d)  The failure of the owner to receive such notice, shall not affect the right to foreclose the lien for unpaid utility bills. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, "utility service" means any utility service except for residential solid waste collection service. 
(Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Secs. 66-77-66-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POTABLE WATER SERVICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Backflow prevention, § 10-66 et seq. 

Sec. 66-101. - Turn-ons; unauthorized connection; resale; construction water. 
(a)  No water from the town water supply shall be turned on for service into any premises by any person except the duly authorized official or employee of the public works department. 
(b)  No person shall connect any pipe, tube or other instrument with any main, service pipe, conduit or flume for conducting water belonging to the town, for any purpose without a permit or other express written authorization from the proper authorities of the town. No utility service that has been terminated by the town shall be reestablished except as provided in section 66-75. 
(c)  Except for construction/temporary use water, water shall be turned on only in compliance with section 66-5. Connection to fire hydrants for construction/temporary use water shall be governed by the provisions of subparagraph (f) of this section. 
(d)  No water shall be turned on for service to premises in which the plumbing does not comply with the provisions of this chapter or ordinances of the town; provided, however, that water may be turned on for construction work in unfinished buildings, subject to the provisions of this chapter. All plumbing fixtures and methods of installation shall comply with the requirements of the plumbing code, as adopted by the town. 
(e)  No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the town supply to any premises other than for which application has been made and the meter installed, except in case of emergency. 
(f)  No person shall connect any pipe, tube, hose or other instrument with any fire hydrant of the town for construction/temporary use water purposes except in compliance with this subsection. 
(1)  The following definitions shall apply to this subsection: 
    Construction/temporary use water shall mean water used by a person other than the town during grading, land preparation or construction on any parcel or lot in the town, for filling swimming pools in the town, or for other one time or short term uses approved by the public works director. 
    Fire hydrant shall mean any fire hydrant owned by the town. 
    Permittee shall mean a person who has been issued a permit to use construction/temporary use water. 
(2)  No construction water from fire hydrants shall be used on parcels or lots of ten acres or more in size, provided however, the director of public works is authorized to issue a permit for construction water to be used on parcels or lots ten acres or more in size if he determines any of the following conditions exist: (i) if construction water from fire hydrants is not made available, an unsafe work environment will exist, (ii) an alternative non-potable water supply is not available, or (iii) it is economically infeasible to obtain an alternative non-potable water supply. In all cases, the permittee has the burden to establish that the conditions exist to justify use of construction water from fire hydrants. 
(3)  For parcels or lots less than ten acres in size, construction water from fire hydrants may be used only with a permit issued by the town. 
(4)  The council shall establish construction/temporary use water rates by resolution. 
(5)  Permits to use construction/temporary use water from fire hydrants may be issued by the town upon written application made to the water section of public works. The permit shall identify the fire hydrant from which the permittee may withdraw construction/temporary use water. Construction/temporary use water used shall be as determined by a meter installed by town on the fire hydrant. All such permits shall be conditioned on the following: 
a.  The permittee shall deposit with the town an amount determined by the water section of the public works department to cover the estimated replacement cost of the meter and related hardware. If town subsequently determines the deposit is not sufficient to cover these costs, permittee shall deposit such additional amount as town establishes for such purposes. Failure to pay such additional amount shall result in revocation of the permit. 
b.  The permittee shall pay the cost of construction/temporary use water within 30 days of the date of an invoice from town. Failure to pay amounts due within 30 days shall result in revocation of the permit. Upon revocation or expiration of the permit, town shall refund to permittee only that portion of the deposit not required to pay all amounts owed to town for construction/temporary use water, meters and related hardware. If an amount is owed in excess of the deposit, permittee shall pay all additional amounts owed to town. No new permit for construction/temporary use water shall be issued to the permittee until all amounts owed pursuant to this section have been paid. 
c.  The meter shall be installed, removed or relocated only by Town of Gilbert Personnel. 
d.  The permittee shall pay all costs related to damage to or theft of the meter and related hardware. 
e.  Construction/temporary use water used for non-construction purposes shall only be authorized for one permittee a total of 30 days in one calendar year. If such water is used for construction purposes, the term of the permit shall be as set forth in the permit. 
(Code 1984, § 9-1-4; Ord. No. 1437, § I, 10-29-02; Ord. No. 1636, § I, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 2292, § I, 6-22-10; Ord. No. 2416, § I, 1-17-13) 
Sec. 66-102. - Meters; installation, reading and testing. 
(a)  All premises using water obtained from the town must be equipped with an adequate water meter furnished by the town but paid for by the consumer. A water meter shall be installed before any premises are occupied in a location that will be of easy access. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to receive water on any lot within the town unless the director of public works shall have placed or directed the placing of a water meter upon each lot. When a lot with multiple buildings served by a single meter is further subdivided, a separate meter shall be required for each lot. If the owner, builder, contractor or developer fails to provide a separate meter for each subdivided lot, or diverts water from a water main without metering the water so diverted, the town may revoke or suspend the building permit or order the owner, builder, contractor or developer to cease and desist all construction activities on the subdivision until such separate meters are installed. Violations of this section shall result in a penalty of up to $2,500.00 per day per violation for each day the violation continues. 
(c)  The director of public works shall read or cause to be read every water meter used for delivery of water supplied by the town at such times as are necessary in order that bills may be sent out at the proper time as may be directed by the town authorities. 
(d)  Upon presentation of a verified complaint of the consumer and payment of the meter test fee established by the council to the director of public works, a municipal water meter shall be taken out and tested. If upon testing the meter is not within three percent of being accurate, it shall be repaired or replaced, and the meter test fee shall be credited to the consumer's next bill. The town shall have no obligation to test any meter more than once during a consecutive 12-month period. 
(e)  If a tested meter is found to be more than three percent in error, the correction of previous bills will be made to the customer last served by the meter tested under the following terms allowing the town to recover or refund the difference: 
(1)  The town shall adjust the customer's billing for consumption back to the date the meter error occurred or for a six-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. If the customer has been underbilled, the town will allow the customer to repay the difference over length of time equal to that of the underbillings or for a six-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. The customer will be allowed to pay the underbilling amount without penalties, interest or late fees, unless there is evidence of meter tampering or water diversion. Any underbilled amounts due by customer as the result of tampering or diversion shall be immediately due and payable. 
(2)  If it is determined that the customer has been overbilled and there is no evidence of meter tampering or water diversion, the town will credit the account in an amount equal to the amount overcharged for the period of time such overbilling occurred or for six months, whichever is shorter in duration the corrected billing shall occur within the next billing cycle. If the account is closed, or the credit exceeds three months of utility service, the customer may request the credit be refunded to him after outstanding utility bills are paid. 
(f)  If a meter is found to be non-functional (registering zero consumption) the correction of previous bills will be made to the customer last served by the meter by adjusting the customer's billing back to the date the meter error occurred or for a six-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. The town will allow the customer to repay the difference over the length of time equal to that of the underbillings or for a six-month period, whichever is shorter in duration. The customer will be allowed to pay the under billing amount without penalties, interest or late fees, unless there is evidence of meter tampering or water diversion. Any underbilled amounts due by customer as the result of tampering or diversion shall be immediately due and payable. Non-functional meters need not be tested, however, subject to the provisions of this section, the customer may request that a non-functional meter be tested. Requests for testing must be made within 60 days of the date the adjusted billing statement is generated. 
(Code 1984, § 9-1-5; Ord. No. 1819, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2313, § I, 12-9-10) 
Sec. 66-103. - Water service equipment. 
(a)  All shutoff valves on the public water system are installed by the town for the use of the public works department. Such shutoff valves shall not be used or in any way molested or manipulated by consumers of water. All consumers shall provide their own valve for ordinary usage. This valve shall be located on the consumer's side of the meter ahead of the first water outlet. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to knowingly have and keep in his possession or under his control any curb cock key, valve key or hydrant wrench to the town water supply system, and no person shall, without authority from the public works department, make, construct, buy, sell or in any way dispose of to any person any curb cock key, valve key or hydrant wrench for use on the town water supply system. 
(Code 1984, § 9-1-6) 
Secs. 66-104-66-110. - Reserved.
