(5)  Applicable civil and criminal penalties for violation of pretreatment requirements, and any applicable compliance schedule. Such schedule may not extend the time for compliance beyond that required by applicable federal, state, or local law. 
(6)  It is unlawful for a permittee to change its industrial process without approval of the director, if such change results in the user exceeding the levels for flow and discharge quality stated in the user's permit. 
(7)  The town, or the town jointly with representatives of the cities of Phoenix or Mesa, may, at any reasonable time, inspect and test any of the wastes being discharged by the company or plant for quality or quantity. A duly authorized town representative may enter the permittee's premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting plant operations to estimate the quality and quantity of wastes. 
(8)  The permittee will install and maintain flow monitoring and sampling point facilities at the permittee's expense, for the purpose of the town's representative inspecting, observing, and sampling representative flows. 
(9)  Periodic monitoring or other reports set forth in this article, or as required by the director, shall be submitted to the director. 
(10)  The permittee, at least 90 days prior to commencing with any new industrial discharges or any additional industrial discharges which exceed flow levels or quality set forth within the permit, shall apply for a new or amended permit. Any such discharges shall be prohibited until the town grants advance approval of the new or amended permit. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-189. - Additional permit conditions 
    In addition to the standard permit requirements set forth in section 66-188, the director may require a permit to include the following: 
(1)  A plan to control slug discharges and spills, to include at a minimum: 
a.  A description of discharge practices, including nonroutine batch discharges; 
b.  A description of stored chemicals; and 
c.  Procedures to prevent adverse impact from accidental spills, including inspection and maintenance of storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants (including solvents), and/or measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(2)  Pollution prevention and/or waste minimization to reduce or eliminate the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW. 
(3)  Best management practices to reduce or eliminate the amount of pollutants discharged to the POTW. 
(4)  Other conditions and requirements as deemed reasonably necessary by the director to prevent pass through or interference, protect the quality of the water body receiving the treatment plant's effluent, protect worker health and safety, facilitate sludge management and disposal, protect against damage to the POTW, and ensure user compliance with this article, state and federal laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-190. - Effect of issuance of permit; modification. 
(a)  Effect of issuance. Issuance of a permit shall not release the permittee from the obligation to comply with all other provisions of this article. 
(b)  Modification. The town may change the conditions of any permit, from time to time, as circumstances or laws or regulations enacted by the state or federal government may require. Upon the effective date of any federal categorical pretreatment standards for a particular industrial subcategory, the federal standard, if more stringent than the effluent limitations imposed under this article, shall immediately supersede those limitations. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-191. - Permit renewal. 
(a)  Renewal of permit. A permittee, upon continued compliance with the terms and conditions established by this article, may file an application for renewal of an industrial wastewater discharge permit. Those users seeking renewal of a permit shall pay the nonrefundable application fee established by resolution of the town council and file the report with the application for renewal no later than 60 days prior to the expiration date of the current permit. The report shall include, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has made any changes in its operations that have or will, within the terms of the permit, increase the strength, volume, or any other characteristic of the applicant's discharge into the town sanitary sewer system. 
(2)  If the applicant has made changes in its operations that have or will increase during the term of the permit, the strength, volume or any other characteristics of the user's discharge into the town sewer system, then: 
a.  The applicant shall describe the changes in operations that alter the strength, volume, or any other characteristics of the discharge. 
b.  The applicant shall, if the director so requires, submit an analysis, complete with sampling and analysis techniques prescribed in 40 CFR 136 and amendments thereto and conducted in accordance with section 66-180. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a permit holder to change its industrial process without approval of the director, if such change results in the user exceeding the levels for flow and discharge quality stated in the user's permit. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-192. - Permit transfers. 
(a)  Individual wastewater discharge permits may be transferred to a new owner or operator only if the permittee gives at least 30 days advance notice to the director and the director approves the individual permit transfer. 
(b)  The notice to the director must include a written certification by the new owner or operator which: 
(1)  States that the new owner and/or operator have no immediate intent to change the facility's operations and processes; 
(2)  Identifies the specific date on which the transfer is to occur; and 
(3)  Acknowledges full responsibility for complying with the existing individual permit. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-193. - Permit revocation. 
    A permit may be revoked by the director for good cause including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Failure to notify the director of significant changes to the wastewater prior to the changed discharge; 
(2)  Failure to provide prior notification to the director of changed conditions pursuant to section 66-187(1); 
(3)  Misrepresentation or failure to fully disclose all relevant facts in the wastewater discharge application; 
(4)  Falsifying self-monitoring reports; 
(5)  Tampering with monitoring equipment; 
(6)  Refusing to allow the director timely access to the facility premises and records; 
(7)  Failure to meet effluent limitations; 
(8)  Failure to pay fines; 
(9)  Failure to pay sewer charges; 
(10)  Failure to meet compliance schedules; 
(11)  Failure to complete a wastewater survey or the permit application; 
(12)  Failure to provide advance notice of the transfer of business ownership of a permitted facility; or 
(13)  Violation of any pretreatment standard or requirement, or any terms of the permit or requirement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-194. - Permit appeals process. 
(a)  Any permit applicant or permittee (aggrieved party) may petition the director to reconsider the conditions and limitations of a permit issued or amended under the authority of this section by filing a petition for review with the director within 20 days of receipt of the permit. 
(b)  Failure to submit a timely petition for review shall be deemed a waiver of the administrative appeal. 
(c)  In its petition, the aggrieved party must identify the permit provisions objected to, specify in detail the reasons for objection, and present the alternative condition, if any, it seeks to place in the permit. 
(d)  The provisions of the permit that are not objected to shall not be stayed pending the appeal. 
(e)  If the director fails to act within 30 days from receipt of the petition, the petition shall be deemed to be denied. Decisions not to reconsider the issued or amended permit, not to issue a permit, or not to amend a permit shall be considered final administrative actions for purposes of judicial review. 
(f)  The aggrieved party seeking judicial review of the final permit decision may file a complaint with the county superior court. 
(Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Secs. 66-195-66-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Discharge of water into town drainage basins, § 42-33. 

Sec. 66-231. - Limitations and prohibitions. 
(a)  Determination of acceptability. The director shall determine the acceptability of any discharge to the sewer system. Such determination shall be made on the basis of sound engineering and operational evaluations, taking into consideration the nature and concentration of the discharge, its point of entry into the system, its compatibility with other discharges in the system, its compatibility with the treatment facility receiving it and all other factors pertinent to the effect of the discharge on any part of the system or treatment process. 
(b)  Prohibited discharges. It shall be unlawful for any user to discharge or cause to be discharged to any entry point into the sanitary sewer system: 
(1)  Materials or substances that would constitute a hazard to life or limb of personnel engaged in inspection, maintenance, and operation of the system. 
(2)  Materials or substances that are toxic. 
(3)  Materials or substances that are in any way deleterious to any part of the system. 
(4)  Materials or substances that cause the municipality to incur excessive expense in treating the materials or substances. 
(5)  Materials or substances that are incompatible with the treatment process, inhibit the performance of the treatment process at a town facility, or otherwise constitute interference or pass through. 
(6)  Materials or substances that are of such volume or contain such concentration of BOD, suspended solids, or other material load that would cause the treatment facility to exceed its design capabilities. 
(7)  Materials or substances that cause a treatment facility of the town to fail to meet effluent requirements set by state and federal regulatory agencies, or cause such effluent to have a degrading effect on the receiving body of water. 
(8)  Materials or substances that contain viable pathogenic organisms in such quantities as to be a hazard to public health. 
(9)  Construction materials, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastic, wood, paunch manure, fur, wax, animal fats, oil and grease, petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil, products of mineral oil origin or any solid or viscous substance in amounts capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, interference with the proper operation of the sewer system, or damage to the sewer system or treatment plant. 
(10)  Pollutants that create a fire or explosion hazard to the system or treatment plant. In no case shall pollutants be discharged that exhibit a closed cup flashpoint less than 140 degrees Fahrenheit (60 degrees Celsius), or pollutants that cause an exceedance of ten percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) at any point within the wastewater treatment plant for any single reading or more than five percent for any two consecutive readings. 
(11)  Any waters with a temperature greater than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (66 degrees Celsius) or heat in amounts that will inhibit biological activity in the POTW resulting in interference, but in no event heat in such quantities that the temperature at the headworks of the POTW exceeds 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius). 
(12)  Coal tar, its derivatives and waste. 
(13)  Any liquids or wastes exhibiting toxic, radioactive, corrosive, reactive, poisonous or other qualities in sufficient quantity or rate of flow to cause or have the potential to cause injury or damage to a person or property or interference with any sewage treatment process, to cause corrosive structural damage, to constitute a hazard to humans or to create any hazard to the sewage system. 
(14)  Any pollutants that result in the presence of gases, vapors, or fumes within the sewer system or POTW at levels that may cause acute worker health and safety problems. 
(15)  Unless otherwise approved by the director, any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, surface drainage, cooling water, or unpolluted process water. 
(16)  Any water or waste that has, in any way, been diluted as a substitute for pretreatment for the purpose of obtaining compliance with any categorical standard or pretreatment requirement imposed by this division, except where dilution is expressly authorized by any categorical standard. 
(17)  Any water or waste that could cause a violation of any categorical standard or pretreatment requirement. 
(18)  Any water or waste that is transported from the point of generation to the sewer system or POTW by any person, including but not limited to, any septic tank waste pumper, chemical waste hauler, or similarly transported, unless a class A or class B permit has been issued. 
(19)  Any discharge that exhibits a characteristic of a hazardous waste, or contains a substance that is listed as a hazardous waste pursuant to either Arizona Administrative Code R18-8-261, as amended or 40 CFR 261, as amended, whichever is applicable, whether or not the discharge is otherwise subject to hazardous waste regulations. This provision does not apply to domestic wastewater or to discharges of hazardous wastes that are authorized by the director. 
(20)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.0 standard units or greater than 10.5 standard units. The director has the authority to adopt, implement, and enforce a policy on waivers from the pH low and high limits. 
(21)  Any water or waste discharged to the system that exceeds the instantaneous concentration limit for the following local limits that are expressed in the total form, unless otherwise indicated: 
Parameter Instantaneous limit Unit Benzene 35 µg/l* Chloroform 2,000 µg/l  
*micrograms per liter 
(22)  Any water or waste containing any of the following prohibited substances: 
4,4' - DDE 
4.4' - DDT 
ALDRIN 
BHC-alpha 
BHC-beta 
BHC-gamma (Lindane) 
Heptachlor 
Heptachlor Epoxide 
Polychlorinated Biphenyl Compounds (PCBs) 
(c)  Authority of director to establish limitations and charges. In addition to the prohibitions and effluent limitations contained in this division, the director shall have the authority to: 
(1)  Establish limitations and charges for individual users or class of users for various pollutants, materials, waters, or wastes, including swimming pool wastewater, that can be accepted into the sewer system. 
(2)  Specify those pollutants, materials, waters, or wastes that are prohibited from entering the sewer system. 
(3)  Identify those pollutants, materials, waters or wastes that shall be controlled with best management practices. 
(d)  Prohibitions and effluent limitations. All prohibitions and effluent limitations so established shall be placed on file with the clerk and will become effective and enforceable on the 31st day after the date of filing. 
(e)  Applicability. All affected individual users or class of users shall comply with the prohibitions, and effluent limitations established pursuant to this section. 
(f)  Pollutants, materials, etc. Pollutants, materials, waters or wastes to be controlled with best management practices that have been identified by the director shall be placed on file with the clerk and will become effective and enforceable on the 31st day after the date of the filing. 
(g)  Preparation of discharges containing garbage. Any discharge to the town sewer system containing garbage may be made acceptable by means of grinding and dilution; provided, however, that the installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric), or greater, shall be subject to review and approval by the director prior to such installation and operation, and to periodic inspection by the director thereafter. 
(h)  Maximum inflow/infiltration rate permissible. The maximum inflow/infiltration rate allowed for discharges into the sewer system shall be 200 gallons per day, per inch of pipe diameter, per mile of pipe line. An individual user's inflow/infiltration rate shall be checked out by testing procedures performed in accordance with the Uniform Standards and Specifications for Public Works Construction, as sponsored and distributed by the county association of governments, published July 1, 1974, and as amended by yearly supplements, as adopted in chapter 54. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04; Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Cross reference- Discharge of water into town drainage basins, § 42-33. 
Sec. 66-232. - Significant industrial user-Class A permits. 
(a)  Each industrial user who discharges an industrial discharge into the sewer system and is designated, as a significant industrial user (SIU) by the director shall: 
(1)  Obtain a class A wastewater discharge permit from the director. Any application for a class A permit or an amended class A permit shall contain the information specified in section 66-187 and the application form or such other information as may be requested by the director. Any person intending to commence any new industrial discharge, or any additional industrial discharge not already allowed pursuant to an existing permit, shall apply for a new or amended permit at least 90 days prior to initiating such discharge. 
(2)  Provide all of the pretreatment necessary to comply with the categorical standards, pretreatment requirements, and best management practices imposed by this article. 
(3)  Meet the requirements of subsection 66-231(b), prohibited discharges. 
(4)  Ensure that no discharge exceeds the following local limits, expressed in the total form: 
Parameter Daily average limit* Unit Arsenic 0.13 mg/l** Cadmium 0.047 mg/l Copper 1.5 mg/l Cyanide 2.0 mg/l Lead 0.41 mg/l Mercury 0.0023 mg/l Selenium 0.1 mg/l Silver 1.2 mg/l Zinc 3.5 mg/l  
*Limits applied at sampling location to be determined by director 
**milligrams per liter 
(5)  Maintain a continuous discharge record which clearly identifies the: 
a.  Dates and times of all industrial discharges; and 
b.  Nature, concentrations, and volumes of all such discharges. 
(6)  Provide the director with all the same self-monitoring reports and notices which the SIU is required to submit to any other authority in accordance with the provisions of 40 CFR 403.12 and section 66-183. 
(7)  Comply with all reporting requirements and maintain records of all information resulting from any monitoring activities as required by this division. 
(8)  Records required by subsections (5), (6) and (7) of this section shall be required to be retained for a minimum of three years from the date of monitoring activity and shall be made available for inspection and copying. This period of retention shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation between the SIU and the POTW. Such records shall include for all samples: 
a.  The date, exact place, method, and time of sampling and the names of the person or persons asking the samples; 
b.  The dates the analyses were performed; 
c.  Who performed the analyses; 
d.  The analytical techniques/methods used; and 
e.  The results of such analyses. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04; Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-233. - Special discharges-Class B permits. 
(a)  The following types of industrial users who are not significant industrial users may be required to obtain a class B wastewater discharge permit if the director determines the industrial discharge causes or has the reasonable potential to cause harm or damage to the POTW, worker safety, public safety, or the environment: 
(1)  Zero process discharge users. 
(2)  Users, which discharge the equivalent strength of 25,000 gallons per day of domestic waste as measured by SS, BOD, or COD. 
(3)  Discharges of polluted groundwater. 
(4)  Users discharging any of the substances identified in sections 66-231 and 66-232. 
(b)  The industrial user shall comply with all requirements and conditions of a class B wastewater discharge permit issued by the director, including: 
(1)  Specified local limits listed in subsection 66-232(a)(4). 
(2)  Provide all of the pretreatment necessary to comply with, pretreatment requirements, and best management practices imposed by this article. 
(3)  Meet the requirements of subsection 66-231(b), prohibited discharges. 
(4)  Maintain a continuous discharge record, which clearly identifies the: 
a.  Dates and times of all industrial discharges; and 
b.  Nature, concentrations, and volumes of all such discharges. 
(5)  Provide the director with all the same self-monitoring reports and notices, which the industrial user is required to submit to any other authority in accordance with the provisions of 40 CFR 403.12 and section 66-183. 
(6)  Comply with all reporting requirements and maintain records of all information resulting from any monitoring activities as required by this division. 
(7)  Records required by subsections (4), (5) and (6) of this section shall be required to be retained for a minimum of three years from the date of monitoring activity and shall be made available for inspection and copying. This period of retention shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation between the IU and the POTW. Such records shall include for all samples: 
a.  The date, exact place, method, and time of sampling and the names of the person or persons asking the samples; 
b.  The dates the analyses were performed; 
c.  Who performed the analyses; 
d.  The analytical techniques/methods used; and 
e.  The results of such analyses. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04; Ord. No. 2323, § I, 4-7-11) 
Sec. 66-234. - Industrial pretreatment. 
(a)  Required. Pretreatment will be required in the following instances, and the director shall submit to the permit applicant the pretreatment levels which must be obtained: 
(1)  If the director determines upon the initial application for a permit under this division that the proposed industrial waste must be pretreated by the applicant to lower the level of any of the components of the industrial waste discharge to the town sewer. 
(2)  If the town must improve the discharge from its wastewater treatment plant, then, and in that event, the director shall require that a permit holder install or enlarge pretreatment facilities to lower the affected component of the permittee's industrial waste discharge. 
(3)  If any wastewater prohibited under the conditions of this article is produced, such producer shall pretreat the wastewater to the extent required, to comply with the standards established in this division before discharging to any town sewer. 
(4)  The acceptability of a pretreatment method for any given discharge, an application for which has been made in accordance with this division, and the terms for the installation and use thereof shall be reviewed by the director. Such a review shall be made on the basis of sound engineering and operational evaluations, taking into consideration all factors pertinent to the effect of the discharge, both before and after pretreatment on any part of the system. 
(5)  Pretreatment facilities shall at all times be subject to inspection by the director or to a joint inspection by the director and the Cities of Phoenix or Mesa in order to determine if such facilities are efficiently performing the function for which they are installed or are in compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(6)  If the director determines that a permittee, because of plant expansion and/or changes in plant operations, has increased either the strength or volume of the discharge, the director may require additional pretreatment to lower the level of the volume and/or any components of the industrial waste before discharge, unless such permittee has previously made industrial cost recovery payments for reservation of additional industrial capacity. Pretreatment facilities required under subsection (a) of this section shall be provided, operated, and maintained at the permitholder's expense. The owner shall keep written records and documentation of all cleaning, repair, calibration, and maintenance required to demonstrate compliance with this section. Records shall be kept at the facility for a minimum of three years and be made available to the director upon request. 
(b)  Disposal of sludge or other materials. Any sludge or other material removed from the industrial waste by the pretreatment facility shall be disposed of in accordance with applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(c)  Dilution. Dilution or commingling as a partial or complete substitute for adequate treatment of waste discharged to the town sanitary sewer system is prohibited, whether accomplished by the combination of two or more wastestreams by a producer or producers, or by the addition of other liquids solely for the purpose of diluting the quality of the waste discharge. 
(d)  Submission of plans for pretreatment facilities. Detailed plans showing any pretreatment facilities shall be submitted to the director for approval before construction of the facilities. The review of such plans will in no way relieve such permit holders from the responsibility of modifying and operating the facilities to produce an effluent complying with the established conditions of the permit and federal regulations. Any subsequent, significant changes in the approved facilities or method of operation shall be reported to the director and must be reviewed and approved by the director as complying with the provisions established in this section. Furthermore, all facilities, methods of operation and discharges must comply with the rules and regulations contained in 40 CFR 403 including, but not limited to, categorical pretreatment standards. 
(e)  Approval; filing of pretreatment plant construction plans. After the construction plans for such pretreatment plants have been approved and a permit issued, the plans shall be placed on file in permanent, reproducible form with the director, without cost to the town, before a building permit will be issued. 
(f)  Compliance of pretreatment facilities with director's demand to halt discharges. Pretreatment facilities shall comply with the demand of the director to immediately halt any actual or threatened discharge to the POTW when the director has given notice that such actual or threatened discharge of pollutants reasonably appears to present an imminent endangerment to the health or welfare of persons or which presents or may present an endangerment to the environment or threatens to interfere with the operations of the POTW. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, damage, or destroy any monitoring equipment with the knowledge or intention of altering the sampling analysis or readings or causing damage or destruction of the monitoring/sampling equipment being utilized to determine compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Secs. 66-235-66-242. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES 

Sec. 66-243. - Authority of the director to require best management practices. 
(a)  The director has the authority to require individual users or class of users to implement best management practices for any pollutant. 
(b)  All affected individual users or class of users shall comply with any best management practices required by the director. 
(c)  The director may establish standards for any industrial wastes not specifically referred to in this chapter. Said standards shall be published and shall be made available to any person requesting a copy of said standards. 
(d)  The director requires that where installed; 
(1)  All pretreatment devices must be maintained by the owner/operator, at their expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(2)  The owner/operator shall keep written records and documentation of all cleaning, repair, calibration, and maintenance required demonstrating compliance with this division. 
(3)  Records shall be kept at the facility for a minimum of three years and be made available to the director upon request. 
(4)  All pretreatment devices shall be easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-244. - Requirements for food service facilities. 
(a)  The owner/operator of every newly constructed, remodeled, or converted commercial user facility or industrial user facility with one or more grease generating activities, shall install or cause to be installed a grease removal device, of a size equal to or greater than the minimum size required by the plumbing code adopted by the town and referenced in the Gilbert Municipal Code section 10-34, as may be amended from time to time. Sizing criteria are also available for review at the department of public works, wastewater quality branch. 
(b)  Upon notification by the director the owner/operator of every commercial user facility or industrial user facility which generates grease, serviced by a sewer collection line found to have a grease blockage, a history of grease blockage, or accelerated line maintenance resulting from grease disposal shall install or cause to be installed, a grease removal device. If a grease removal device is already installed then the owner/operator may be required to install a new or more effective grease removal device. 
(c)  All grease removal device(s) shall be installed on the premises where grease is used or generated. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers. When bolted covers are required, they shall be gastight and watertight. 
(d)  The contents of all grease removal devices shall be removed periodically as necessary to prevent violations of this chapter. At a minimum, the entire contents shall be removed every six months, or more frequently as needed to prevent carry over of grease into the POTW, unless it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the director that the pumping frequency can be extended past the six-month period. 
(e)  Any commercial user or industrial user utilizing biological or chemical additives, for treatment, remains responsible for maintaining the grease removal device so that it remains effective. Any user utilizing biological or chemical additives must notify the director and provide the material safety data sheets for such additives. 
(1)  The exclusive use of the aforementioned chemicals is not considered an acceptable maintenance practice. Their use cannot be employed as the sole method of treating or maintaining the facility's discharge to the POTW. 
(2)  Emulsifiers are prohibited from use in grease removal devices. The use of emulsifiers in grease removal devices for the purpose of decreasing the service frequency is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-245. - Requirements for vehicle and equipment service facilities. 
    All vehicle and equipment service facilities shall be operated in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  All owners/operators of these facilities shall ensure that any fluid, hazardous material or rinsewater from parts cleaning operations that comes into contact with any floor, pavement, or ground surface is cleaned up immediately from such surface. 
(2)  No person shall dispose of fluids or rinsewater from parts cleaning operations into the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  None of these facilities shall contain floor drains, excepting only such floor drains as are connected to wastewater pretreatment systems. 
(4)  No tanks, containers, or sinks used for parts cleaning or rinsing shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system. 
(5)  No person shall discharge wastewater from washing operations or wash racks to the sanitary sewer system without the wastewater going through a pretreatment device. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the proper reuse of wastewater. 
(6)  These facilities shall be cleaned using only those methods of cleaning that ensure that no materials are discharged to the sanitary sewer system, except for wastewater which is discharged to the sanitary sewer system through a pretreatment device. 
(7)  All owners/operators of these facilities shall ensure that spill prevention and clean-up equipment and absorbent materials are kept in stock at all times and are readily available for use. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-246. - Requirements for machine shops and metal fabrication facilities. 
    All machine shops and metal fabrication facilities shall be operated in accordance with the following standards: 
(1)  No person shall dispose of shop or fabrication fluids or rinsewater from parts cleaning operations into the sanitary sewer system. 
(2)  No machine shop or metal fabrication facility shall contain floor drains, excepting only such floor drains as are connected to wastewater pretreatment systems. 
(3)  All owners/operators of machine shops or metal fabrication facilities shall ensure that spill prevention, cleanup equipment, and absorbent materials are kept in stock at all times and are readily available for use. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-247. - Requirements for silver photo and x-ray development. 
    All silver photo processors shall comply with one or more of the following requirements: 
(1)  Install and operate in their facilities a silver removal system to treat all spent solutions and washwater discharged to the POTW. 
(2)  All spent solutions and washwater may be recycled on-site. 
(3)  All spent solutions and washwater may be shipped off-site for recovery for appropriate disposal. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-248. - Requirements for dental facilities using silver amalgams. 
    Persons who use amalgams containing silver shall install amalgam traps on all equipment that might carry amalgam waste to the sanitary sewer system. Each trap shall be cleaned or replaced according to manufacturer guidelines and in a manner that prevents any captured waste from entering the sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-249. - Requirements for perchloroethylene dry cleaners. 
(a)  All dry cleaners discharging to the POTW, which dry clean with perchloroethylene on-site, are required to not discharge separator water directly or indirectly to the sewer (zero discharge). Wastewater from boilers, vacuum tanks, sinks, and restrooms that are not contaminated by separator wastewater may be allowed to discharge to the POTW. 
(b)  Zero discharge of perchloroethylene-contaminated water is met by completing the following requirements: 
(1)  Seal or secure from spills and accidental discharges all floor drains in areas where perchloroethylene is stored or used. Cement plugs, standpipes or berms may be used for this purpose. 
(2)  Choose one of the following approved separator wastewater disposal methods and comply with associated requirements: 
a.  Off-site waste hauling disposal manifests must be kept on-site for at least three years and must be made available to the director upon request. 
b.  On-site evaporation to the atmosphere evaporators must vent to the atmosphere and have no connection to the sewer or any equipment that discharges to the sewer such as boilers, cooling towers or vacuum trucks. It is the responsibility of the dry cleaner to be aware of, and comply with, any regulations pertaining to the operation of an evaporator. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 66-250. - Requirements for in-home carpet and drapery cleaners. 
    Wash water from in-home carpet and drapery cleaners must be discharged to the sanitary sewer and a lint trap or filter must be used. The lint or fibers may not be disposed of to the POTW, but may be disposed to the trash. 
(Ord. No. 1612, § I, 12-14-04) 
DIVISION 4. - CLEANING AND REPAIR OF SEWER LINES 

Sec. 66-251. - Generally. 
(a)  All users shall clean, unstop, and maintain their individual sewer lines, subject to requirements of this article. 
(b)  A user shall make any necessary or prudent repairs to its individual sewer line located on-property, and shall remove any root intrusions from its entire individual sewer line. 
(c)  A user shall notify the town of any necessary or prudent repairs to, or root intrusions in, its individual sewer line located off-property. The town will be responsible for coordinating and making all repairs to individual sewer lines located off-property; provided, however, the town may require a user to reimburse costs associated with off-property repairs to an individual sewer line, if the town reasonably determines the repairs were required as a result of the user's actions. a user shall reimburse the town for such costs within thirty (30) days from receipt of the invoice. 
(d)  If root intrusions are identified in a main sewer line, the owner of the tree or vegetation identified as causing the intrusion will be notified by the town, and the owner shall reimburse the town for all costs to remove the root intrusion and any related necessary or prudent repairs of the main sewer line. The user shall reimburse the town for such costs within thirty (30) days from receipt of the invoice. 
(e)  All repairs to individual sewer lines and to the main sewer line shall be made in compliance with town permitting and construction standards, on file with the development services office. A town building safety inspector must inspect and accept all repairs to the individual sewer line and a town engineering inspector (or authorized agent) must inspect and accept all repairs to the main sewer line before the line is returned to service or use. 
(f)  A violation of this section 66-251 shall be punishable as a civil offense, and imposition of a civil sanction as provided for in subsection 1-5(f) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1791, § I, 6-20-06) 
Secs. 66-252-66-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SOLID WASTE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1820, § I, adopted Aug. 29, 2006, amended Art. VII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VII, §§ 66-286-66-338, 66-341-66-346, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1984, §§ 11-4-1-11-4-7; Ord. No. 1047, § I, adopted July 8, 1997; Ord. No. 1249, § I, adopted Feb. 15, 2000; Ord. No. 1363, § I.7, adopted Aug. 21, 2001; Ord. No. 1504, § I, adopted July 22, 2003. 
Cross reference- Deposits of injurious materials on thoroufares, § 42-108; litter, § 42-231 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 66-261. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Collection employee means any individual employed by the town for the purpose of effectuating the provisions of this division. 
    Commingled means to blend or cause to blend together. 
    Commercial solid waste generator means any person owning, leasing, managing, renting or occupying any business, home-based business, industrial or commercial building, or construction site, which generates refuse, solid waste or recyclables. 
    Contaminate means to spoil, pollute or make unclean so as to make something unfit for use. 
    Director means the director of the department of public works or his designee. 
    Dwelling units means any building or structure used solely as a family domicile, including single-family and multifamily dwelling units, apartments, townhouses, condominiums, rooming houses and boardinghouses, and manufactured homes. 
    License area means the incorporated area of the town and any subsequent annexations thereto, wherein a licensed solid waste contractor is authorized to operate. 
    Licensed solid waste contractor means any person, firm or entity holding a license issued by the town that permits the licensed solid waste collector to operate within the town for the purpose of providing solid waste collection services to commercial solid waste generators. 
    Notice means a written instrument serviced by the town in one of the following manners, with time commencing from date of mailing, serving, filing or recording: 
(1)  By the use of ordinary mail to the last known address of the person to whom it is required to be given. 
(2)  By personal service upon the person or his lawful representative. 
(3)  By filing or recording with the clerk of the superior court or county recorder. 
    Person means, and includes any entity, property owner, manager, agent, tenant or occupant of a property within the town. 
    Premises means land, buildings, or other structures, or parts thereof. 
    Recyclable material or recyclables means any solid waste separated from other solid waste for the purpose of being recycled. Recyclables may include, but are not limited to metals, plastics, glass, cardboard and paper. 
    Recycling means the process of collecting, separating, cleansing, treating, and reconstituting post-consumer materials that would otherwise become solid waste and returning them to the economic stream in the form of raw material for reconstituted products. 
    Recycling container, private means any container not owned by the town, for collection of materials from the public to be donated or left to be recycled, reclaimed, processed or reused including, but not limited to, newspaper, bottles, and cans. 
    Refuse has the same meaning as "solid waste". 
    Solid waste means all wastes and materials discarded. Solid waste includes but is not limited to the following: 
(1)  Bulk trash. All manmade materials that are bulky or cumbersome such as washers, hot water heaters and other appliances, sofas, tables, beds and other large household furniture, yard waste and other refuse items which by size, shape, or quantity will not fit into a residential roll-out container. 
(2)  Construction waste. All waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair and demolition operations on commercial, institutional and industrial establishments, dwelling units, garages, pavements, streets, alleys, trenches, ditches, underground utilities, excavations and other structures. Construction waste includes but is not limited to rocks, debris, dirt, brick, fill, plaster, and all types of scrap building materials, including but not limited to lumber scraps, shingles, plaster, brick, stone, and concrete. 
(3)  Garbage. All putrescible wastes, except sewer and body wastes, including all organic wastes prepared for or intended to be used as food or which have resulted from the preparation of food, including all such substances from public and private establishments and residences. 
(4)  Hazardous waste. Any discarded material hazardous by reason of its pathological, explosive, flammable, radiological, corrosive, reactive, or toxic nature. The term shall mean any material that can cause damage or injury to property or persons. Hazardous waste includes but is not limited to any chemical, compound, mixture, substance, product or other material which is a hazardous waste pursuant to A.R.S. § 49-921 as may be amended from time to time, or Code of Federal Regulations Part 261. 
(5)  Medical sharps. Discarded sharps used in human or animal care, medical research, or clinical laboratories. This includes hypodermic needles, syringes, pipettes, scalpel blades, blood vials, needles attached to tubing, broken and unbroken glassware, and slides and coverslips. The term medical sharps shall have the same definition as set forth in the Arizona Administrative Code R18-13-1401 as may be amended from time to time. 
(6)  Medical waste means any solid waste that is generated in the diagnosis, treatment, or immunization of a human being or animal or in any research relating to that diagnosis, treatment or immunization, or in the production or testing of biologicals, and includes discarded drugs, but does not include hazardous wastes as defined in A.R.S. § 49-921 other than conditionally exempt small quantity generator waste, and shall have the same meaning as set forth in A.R.S. § 49-701 as may be amended from time to time. 
(7)  Trash means rubbish, waste, debris, and all other nonputrescible wastes. 
(8)  Yard waste. Brush, grass and vegetation clippings, weeds, twigs, leaves, limbs, branches and trunks from trees, palm fronds and general yard, garden and tree rubbish and waste materials. 
    Solid waste collection services means the collection and disposal, including the cost of landfills, and other disposal technology required to dispose of solid waste and the collection, sorting, sale and disposal of recyclable materials. 
    Town-supplied containers means those containers supplied to residential or commercial refuse generators by the town, whether or not the cost of the container was paid for by the town. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-262. - Solid waste collection service mandatory; exemptions. 
(a)  Any person within the town's corporate limits who receives other utility service from the town shall pay the cost of town garbage and refuse service, unless such person qualifies for and is granted one of the following exemptions: 
(1)  Residential-agricultural zoned land of a minimum size parcel of ten acres, upon verification by the director. 
(2)  If it can be demonstrated to the satisfaction of the director that the customer's garbage and refuse collection requirements exceed the town's equipment ability or capacity or that the customer has direct responsibility for disposing of the refuse under this division. 
(3)  For the property owner or lessee of any vacant land on which a water meter or service is installed for agricultural, animal husbandry or landscaping only, upon approval of the director. 
(4)  Any commercial or industrial solid waste generator that is utilizing the services of a licensed solid waste contractor as provided in division 3 of this article. 
(5)  Any multi-family residential property solid waste generator, as defined by state law, that is utilizing the services of a licensed solid waste contractor as provided in division 3 of this article, and after at least 60 days' notice to the public works director. 
(6)  Vacant, unoccupied property not receiving utility service. 
(7)  A model home complex not used as a dwelling unit. 
(8)  A residential property receiving residential collection service from the town may utilize the services of a licensed solid waste contractor for collection of horse manure or other animal waste. 
(b)  To be granted, the exemption must be requested upon written application to the town and receive written approval by the director. The director shall act on the application within ten working days. Until granted an exemption by the town, each customer shall pay the refuse charges. 
(c)  The director shall review all exemptions each January to determine their status. Any person determined at that time (or any other time) as not meeting conditions for exemption as set forth in this division shall revert to town refuse collection service and charges upon 30 days written notice. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2601, § I , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 66-263. - Solid waste collection services-General. 
(a)  Service outside town limits . Regular town refuse collection services may be rendered to areas outside the town limits at the option of the town and approval of the council and are subject to termination at any time. The fees for collection in such areas shall be at a rate established by resolution of the council. 
(b)  Commencement of service. For newly constructed structures, town refuse collection charges shall commence upon final inspection and approval of such structures by the permit and plan review services manager unless an exemption is granted pursuant to section 66-262. 
(c)  Town-supplied residential containers. The town shall provide the appropriate containers for all dwelling units serviced by the town's collection system for the accumulation, storage and collection of all solid waste and recyclables. Where a residence with curbside collection requests or is required to maintain more than one refuse container, a charge established by resolution of the council shall be charged for each additional container. 
(d)  Town-supplied commercial containers. The town will provide refuse service to commercial, industrial and institutional customers utilizing containers furnished by town and the collection system which is most practical as prescribed by the director. Container size, number required and number of collection days shall be determined by the director. 
(e)  Town reserves right to deny service. The town reserves the right to deny collection service for refuse which the director determines to be hazardous, and to require the customer to properly dispose of it by other means. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-264. - Access to premises serviced by town. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of property shall ensure the town has convenient access to town solid waste collection containers placed out for collection for the property at all times. 
(b)  It is unlawful to park, maintain, or allow any vehicle or any other kind of obstruction within 15 feet of a solid waste or recycling container placed out for collection service. 
(c)  It is unlawful to close or obstruct any right-of-way, route or loading area interfering with the normal operations of collection service without a permit granted by the town. 
(d)  The owner or occupant of property shall maintain drives, driveways, easements and container enclosures in a manner adequate to prevent solid waste collection vehicles and drivers from injury or damage in performing their work. 
(e)  Areas serviced from and on dirt and unpaved roads, easements or driveways will be at the discretion of the town and subject to the ability to safely access and service the containers without backing more than 50 feet. 
(f)  The owner or occupant of property shall trim trees or shrubbery on his property and in the adjacent right-of-way or easement, so that the trees or shrubbery do not interfere with the free movement of solid waste collection vehicles, and do not obstruct the vision of solid waste collection vehicle drivers in performing their work. 
(g)  Containers shall be placed for collection to meet safety requirements for collection. The town may require owners to place the containers some distance from the property. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-265. - Spilling of refuse during transport. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to haul, or cause to be hauled, on or along any public street, right-of-way or alley in the town, any refuse unless such material is contained in the vehicle or receptacle in a manner that prevents the contents from falling out, leaking, or spilling, and prevents obnoxious odor from escaping. If any refuse falls out, leaks or spills, such person shall immediately clean up the refuse or liquid and notify the town police department. 
(b)  Failure to properly secure a load and any covering of the load to prevent the covering or load from becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard to other users of the highway may be prosecuted as a violation of A.R.S. § 28-1098 as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-266. - Dumping of refuse. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed any refuse upon any public or private property within the town, except as specifically permitted in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-267. - Use of another's containers. 
    It is unlawful for any person to deposit, or cause to be deposited, any refuse in any container not assigned to that person, or not assigned to that person by a licensed solid waste contractor unless such person is authorized to use the container. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-268. - Tampering with container and contents. 
    It is unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To tip over or damage any refuse container; 
(2)  To place decals, markings, or paint on the container; 
(3)  To remove refuse from a container; 
(4)  To climb into a container; 
(5)  To use the container or container lid for something other than its intended purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-269. - Customer responsibilities-General. 
    Every person, owner, tenant or occupant within the town or otherwise receiving solid waste collection service shall: 
(1)  Provide for the collection, control and disposition of refuse in or upon any and all premises owned, leased or occupied by or for them. 
(2)  Cooperate with such agents or agencies as may be provided by law for the collection, control and disposition of refuse. 
(3)  Maintain and keep clean the alley adjacent to the premises owned, leased or occupied by or for them and the area surrounding their refuse containers free from refuse and other health hazards. 
(4)  Place or cause to be placed all refuse accumulated on the premises, owned, leased, or occupied by or for them in receptacles or containers provided to them. 
(5)  Keep lids for refuse containers down in a closed position at all times in order to prevent flies, except when a container is being filled, emptied or cleaned. 
(6)  Maintain refuse containers of sufficient number to accommodate the refuse and recycling disposal needs of such residence, premises or establishment, as determined by the director. 
(7)  Maintain refuse containers in good repair and in sanitary condition, free of any markings or decals not placed on the containers by the town. Containers that have become unserviceable due to ordinary wear and tear will be replaced by the town at no cost to customer. Notice that a container has been determined to be no longer serviceable through conditions other than ordinary wear and tear, or is being maintained in an unsanitary condition, shall be given as provided in section 66-274. If containers supplied by town require cleaning, painting, or refurbishing, then the cost of such work shall be charged to the customer. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-270. - Hazardous waste and special refuse. 
(a)  In general. No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited in any refuse container, anything which will be dangerous or hazardous to the collection equipment or a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the collection employees or general public. 
(b)  Hazardous wastes. Hazardous wastes shall be placed in an appropriate, closed container and plainly and properly marked in accordance with applicable law and industry standards. The director shall be notified and shall instruct the customer as to disposal options for such waste. 
(c)  Explosives. Explosives such as arms, ammunition, war souvenirs or explosive items or powder of any kind and highly flammable materials shall not be placed in any refuse collection container. Persons shall dispose of these items after calling the town police department for directions and disposal options. 
(d)  Acids, caustics and rapid oxidizers. Acids, caustics and rapid oxidizers, including chemicals used in swimming pools, shall not be disposed of in refuse containers. Persons shall dispose of such chemicals after calling the director for containment instructions and disposal options. 
(e)  Coals or ashes. Warm or hot coals or ashes shall not be placed in any container. 
(f)  Dead small animals; livestock. Dead small animals may be placed in plastic bags, tied and placed in the regular refuse container. Dead livestock shall be disposed of by the owner. 
(g)  Dead small animals in public right-of-way. Dead small animals in the public right-of-way will be removed and disposed of by calling the public works department. 
(h)  Medical sharps. Medical sharps may be placed with other refuse for collection, but must be properly contained in a sealed, puncture-resistant container and clearly labeled as such. 
(i)  Lead acid batteries. Lead acid batteries, such as automobile or other vehicle batteries, shall not be disposed of in refuse containers. Persons shall dispose of such waste after calling the director for disposal and recycling options. 
(j)  Waste soil, sand, concrete, rock and similar materials. Waste soil, sand, concrete, masonry block, rock, and similar materials shall be disposed of by the owner, tenant or occupant of the premises (and not by the town) and shall not be stored or placed in the public right-of-way. 
(k)  Construction waste. Debris resulting from the construction, reconstruction, demolition, or repair of premises shall not be placed with other refuse for collection but shall be disposed of directly by the contractor or by the person owning, occupying, or leasing the premises wherein such debris is accumulated. All such wastes shall be removed promptly and shall not be stored in any location where it may be blown or otherwise dispersed beyond the construction site. 
(l)  Manure. Manure generated from livestock on a residential premises, which cannot otherwise be disposed of in the black roll-out containers, may be collected by a licensed solid waste contractor or by the town upon payment of a special collection fee pursuant to section 66-292. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-271. - Refuse container enclosures. 
(a)  Any new or improved fence along a property line abutting an alley or multifamily, commercial or industrial zoning district or property shall be subject to the approval of the director for the need, location, erection, construction or improvement of refuse container enclosures. Standards for refuse enclosures shall be furnished by the director. 
(b)  Only town approved containers shall be kept inside a refuse container enclosure. Private property not intended for collection shall not be kept in the refuse container enclosure area. When the enclosure is also used to store approved grease containers, recycling containers, grass containers, etc., then the size of the enclosure shall be increased to accommodate such. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-272. - Hours of collection. 
    It is unlawful to provide solid waste collection services between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., unless approved in advance in writing by the director. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-273. - State and local authority. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to infringe or supplant the authority of the state or the county health department exercised pursuant to the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-274. - Inspections and container violations. 
(a)  Inspections. Provisions shall be made for regulated inspections by the town to secure compliance with this article. 
(b)  Notification of container violation; tagging. Notice of container violations shall be given by tagging the container with a tag or label with the violations indicated on the tag or label, or by delivering a notice in person or by mail to the owner or occupant. If action necessary to remedy the violation is not taken within ten days, the director may remove the container and dispose of it at the responsible party's expense. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-275. - Violations and citations. 
(a)  The town may issue citations for any violation of this article pursuant to this section, in addition to any other enforcement options specified in this article or section 1-5 of the Code. 
(b)  Any violation of or failure to do or perform any act required by this article constitutes a civil offense, unless the code specifically states that a violation constitutes a class 1 misdemeanor. Repeat offenses are subject to prosecution as a class 1 misdemeanor as specified in section 1-5 of the Code. 
(c)  If a violation continues past the time set forth in the notice of violation, a citation shall be issued to the property owner, person in control or authorized agent of the property; commercial or private hauler; owner or operator of recycling container; or other responsible party as the case may be, subject to the following: 
(1)  An action for violation shall be commenced by filing of the citation in the Gilbert Municipal Court. 
(2)  Citations may be issued by any authorized town official. 
(3)  Each day a violation continues, or the failure to perform any act or duty required by the code or by the Gilbert Municipal Court continues, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(4)  A citation for a civil offense shall direct the person to whom the citation is issued to pay a fine in the amount set forth in the Gilbert's Municipal Court adopted schedule of fines within ten days of receipt of the citation or to appear before the Gilbert Municipal Court. Payment of the fine shall constitute a finding of responsibility for a civil offense. 
(5)  Every civil action or proceeding shall be commenced and prosecuted in accordance with the laws of the State of Arizona relating to civil traffic procedures as described in section 1-5 of the Code. 
(6)  Criminal penalties and/or civil sanctions for violations are in the amounts as described in section 1-5 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Secs. 66-276-66-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTAL COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL SERVICE 

Sec. 66-286. - Town has exclusive right to collect refuse. 
    The town and its duly authorized agents, servants or employees have the exclusive right to collect refuse within the town, except as provided in section 66-262, this chapter, or state law. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-287. - Collection service required. 
(a)  Except as provided in section 66-262 of this article or state law, no person in possession of any dwelling unit within the town shall avoid or refuse to accept the garbage, trash or refuse disposal service provided by the town, and any such avoidance or refusal shall not exempt such premises from the payment of charges for such services. 
(b)  No person may request the town to suspend residential refuse service unless all utilities services are to be discontinued by such person. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-288. - Preparation of refuse for collection. 
(a)  The town will only collect refuse, which is properly prepared for pickup. Any person found to be in violation of a requirement of this section is responsible for a civil offense, subject to citation, civil sanctions, and subject to abatement under sections 66-274 and 66-275. 
(b)  Refuse shall be prepared for pickup as follows: 
(1)  Roll-out containers shall be used for curbside collection of residential refuse. 
(2)  Dwelling unit garbage must be drained of liquids and shall be bagged in plastic bags and tied before being placed in refuse containers. 
(3)  Refuse shall be placed in containers specified for refuse. All boxes, cartons, and crates shall be collapsed before being placed in town supplied containers. Also, large boxes and cartons shall be cut up before being placed in the containers. 
(4)  The town's regular collection service will collect only the refuse which is contained in the town-supplied refuse containers. 
(5)  Residential customers may dispose of yard waste in town-supplied black roll-out containers as long as the yard waste is bagged, and there is room for the regular refuse and such material does not interfere with the emptying of the container in any way. 
(6)  Residential customers may dispose of small amounts of building material, except concrete or masonry, provided it is placed in the residential customer's black roll-out container. 
(7)  The contents of an individual roll-out container shall not exceed 200 pounds. 
(8)  All garbage shall be bagged and securely tied. 
(9)  Wastes from small animals, pets, or livestock shall be placed in a bag, securely tied and then placed in the black roll-out containers. 
(10)  Lids for refuse containers must be kept down in a closed position at all times in order to prevent flies, except when a container is being filled, emptied or cleaned. 
(c)  Recycling. Recyclables shall be prepared for pickup as follows: 
(1)  Recyclables must be reasonably clean, empty, dry and loose, and shall not be bagged or put in sealed box when placed in recycling containers. 
(2)  Only recyclables may be placed in recycling containers. Large boxes and cartons shall be cut up or collapsed before being placed in recycling containers. 
(3)  Recycling collection service will collect only recyclables contained in the recycling containers. 
(4)  Shredded paper must be in a clear plastic bag when placed in recycling containers. 
(d)  Bulk trash. Bulk trash shall be prepared for pickup as follows: 
(1)  Bulk trash is collected on a regular recurring schedule for single-family dwelling units paying for regular refuse service. A special collection requiring additional fees is available, pursuant to section 66-292. 
(2)  A pile up to five feet by five feet by ten feet of combined yard waste and bulk trash shall be collected on a scheduled bulk trash collection. A special collection for larger quantities requiring additional fees is available pursuant to section 66-292. 
(3)  All brush, tree limbs and cuttings shall not exceed five feet in length and 12 inches in diameter. 
(4)  Bulk trash shall be placed for pick up no earlier than the Saturday immediately preceding the designated collection week and no later than Monday at 5:00 a.m. of the designated collection week. 
(5)  Bulk trash shall be placed within the street adjacent to the residential customer's curbline in a manner so as to not interfere with or be hazardous to pedestrians or vehicles. If bulk trash cannot be placed within the street in a manner so as to not interfere with or be hazardous to pedestrians or vehicles, then it shall be placed in plain view on the residential customer's driveway as close to the residential customer's curbline as possible, or in such other area as may be designated by the town. In no event shall refuse containers or public rights-of-way be blocked by placement of the bulk trash materials. All bulk trash shall be placed neatly in a pile, lengthwise parallel to the curb and in a consolidated manner (not dispersed). 
(6)  Bulk trash shall not be placed on sidewalks, curbing, or private property except as provided in this section 66-288(d), or with any mechanized collection container in such a manner as to interfere with its being emptied. 
(7)  Appliances, air conditioners and other items that involve freon gases are not accepted as part of normal bulk trash service. A special collection requiring additional fees pursuant to section 66-292 is available. The customer must take off the locking mechanism off or remove the door from any container or appliance, including freezers, refrigerators, stoves or chests before setting them out for special collection as required by section 42-106 of the Code. 
(8)  Items not accepted for collection will be left. The following are unacceptable materials: Disposable or unwanted material resulting from construction, repair, or demolition of the premises; large auto parts; tires; used oil; rocks, soil-like and concrete materials; unbagged leaves and grass clippings; and vegetation over five feet in length and 12 inches in diameter. These items must be disposed of at a landfill by the owner, lessee or occupant, or by an alternative service, such as roll-off containers. 
(9)  Century plants, cacti, and similar plants hazardous to collection employees shall be contained in cardboard boxes with a total weight not to exceed 60 pounds per box. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2684, § I, 9-6-18 ) 
Sec. 66-289. - Container damage or loss. 
    Each town-supplied container shall be assigned to the property or premises and not to the owner or occupant of the property or premises. No person who occupies any property or premises to which a container has been assigned may remove the container from the assigned property or premises for any reason. The town shall not be responsible for damage or loss of a container, and in the event of damage other than ordinary wear and tear of such container, the person who occupies the property or premises to which a container has been assigned may be charged for such damage or loss, at the option of director. The town will replace containers which fail due to ordinary wear and tear. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-290. - Placement of collection containers. 
(a)  Collection containers must be properly located for pickup. Any person found to be in violation of a requirement of this section is responsible for a civil offense, subject to citation, civil sanctions, and subject to abatement under section 66-274 and 66-275. 
(b)  Collection containers shall be placed in the street at the curb line. A separation of a minimum of three feet is required between containers. One side of street placement may be required to save routing time or distance, as determined by the director. 
(c)  Collection containers shall not be placed for collection before 6:00 p.m. of the day preceding regular collection and shall be removed from the curb by 6:00 a.m. of the day after collection. 
(d)  All containers shall be stored between collection days so as to not be visible from the street or public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-291. - Frequency of residential solid waste collection. 
(a)  The days and hours of collection pickup shall be designated by the director. 
(b)  Regular refuse service shall be supplied once a week to all single-family dwelling units, except those exempt, as provided for in this division. Where more than one refuse container is maintained for a single residence, all containers will be serviced on the same day. 
(c)  The town shall collect bulk trash on a regular recurring schedule from all single-family dwelling units. The times of collection shall be publicized. Bulk trash service shall not be used for waste generated by home occupations or generated off the site, including yard waste generated off the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2684, § I, 9-6-18 ) 
Sec. 66-292. - Special collections. 
    A special collection, for unusual or excess waste materials may be made by the public works department for an additional fee. Customers may request alternate containers and collection services from the public works department. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Secs. 66-293-66-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL AND PRIVATE HAULERS 

Sec. 66-311. - License required. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to provide solid waste collection services within the town without a license. 
(b)  The town retains all jurisdiction granted political subdivisions under A.R.S. § 44-1408 for violations of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-312. - Scope of license. 
(a)  Any license issued pursuant to division 3 of this article authorizes the licensee to use the public rights-of-way to collect solid waste from commercial solid waste generators; or from any person who has a valid, current exemption from town collection service pursuant to section 66-262; or to collect special or hazardous waste as set forth in section 66-270 and in compliance with applicable laws. 
(b)  A license issued pursuant to division 3 does not authorize the licensee to place or keep a private recycling container within the town, a separate permit is required for this activity pursuant to division 4. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-313. - License applications. 
(a)  All applications for a license to provide solid waste collection services shall be filed with the development services director at least 30 days prior to the date the applicant intends to commence business or the expiration of an existing license. 
(b)  Each application shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  A detailed statement of the corporate or other business entity organization of the applicant. 
(3)  The names and business addresses of all officers, directors and partners of the applicant. 
(4)  The names and addresses of any parent or subsidiary of the applicant and of any other business entity owning or controlling in whole or in part or owned or controlled in whole or in part by the applicant and a statement describing the nature of any such parent or subsidiary business entity, including but not limited to all solid waste collection systems owned or controlled by the applicant, its parent or subsidiary and the areas served thereby, within the state. 
(5)  A detailed description of all previous experience of the applicant in providing solid waste collection service or related or similar services. 
(6)  A description of any violations of a solid waste hauling license made by applicant's solid waste collection company or its successor in interest within the last three years. 
(7)  A copy of a current certificate(s) of insurance for the applicant's business operations in Arizona. 
(8)  A copy of a current permit issued by the Maricopa County Environmental Services Department for solid waste collection. 
(9)  Any other information deemed pertinent to the subject matter of such application and requested by the town manager or his designee. 
(10)  An application fee in the amount of $500.00, which shall be in a form acceptable to the town. The application fee is nonrefundable. 
(c)  Upon receiving the application for a license for solid waste collection services to commercial generators, the town manager or his designee shall review the application and prepare a report. The town manager shall determine whether the license shall be granted or denied based on the factors set forth in section 66-318. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-314. - License fee. 
(a)  In consideration of the granting and exercise of a license to use the streets and public rights-of-ways and to operate within the town to collect solid waste from commercial solid waste generators, a solid waste contractor shall pay to the town an annual license fee as established by council resolution. Such license fee shall be paid within ten days from issuance of the license, and within 30 days prior to each subsequent anniversary date of the issuance of the license. 
(b)  The council shall have the right to adjust the annual license charge. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-315. - License conditions. 
(a)  It is the policy of the town to encourage competition in the furnishing of solid waste collection services. A solid waste contractor license grants a non-exclusive license to provide solid waste collection services to commercial solid waste generators within the town. 
(b)  A solid waste contractor license shall not exceed a one-year term. 
(c)  A licensed solid waste contractor shall indemnify and hold the town harmless from any loss, harm, claim, cost or liability of any kind arising out of any operation of the licensee. The licensee shall agree to reimburse the town for all costs including litigation costs and attorney fees in connection with any such claim or liability. 
(d)  At all reasonable times, the licensed solid waste contractor shall permit any duly authorized representative of the town to examine all property of the licensed solid waste contractor, together with any appurtenant property of the licensed solid waste contractor situated within or without the town, and to examine and transcribe any and all maps and other records kept or maintained by the licensed solid waste contractor or under its control which relate to license compliance and deal with the operations, affairs, transactions or property of the licensed solid waste contractor. Contractors can identify confidential records which may impact competition to be excluded from inspection. 
(e)  A license shall not become effective until the applicant solid waste contractor has executed the license. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-316. - Prohibited practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any solid waste contractor providing solid waste collection services within the town to engage in any of the following practices: 
(1)  Failure to comply with any provision of division 1, division 3, division 4 or of a license between the town and licensed solid waste contractor. 
(2)  Providing solid waste collection services to commercial waste generators in the town without a valid license issued pursuant to this division. 
(3)  Failure to comply with any of the provisions of Title 49, Arizona Revised Statutes or Arizona Administrative Code, Title 18, Chapter 8 or any applicable county regulation. 
(4)  To contract, combine or conspire with one or more other licensed solid waste contractors under this chapter or persons for the purpose of restraining competition or limiting competition for the provision of solid waste collection services to commercial generators. 
(5)  To violate the Arizona Uniform Anti-Trust Act as set forth in A.R.S. § 44-1401, et seq. 
(6)  To provide solid waste collection services between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-317. - Identification of vehicles and containers. 
(a)  Solid waste contractors shall mark all vehicles used in providing solid waste collection services within the town, in legible print with letters of a minimum height of three inches, with licensed solid waste contractor's company name and local customer service telephone number. 
(b)  All solid waste and recycling containers shall be identifiable by indicating the responsible party's name and telephone number on the container. The container identification must be readable from a minimum of ten feet. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06; Ord. No. 2285, § I, 5-25-10) 
Sec. 66-318. - Cause for denial, modification or revocation of license. 
(a)  Solid waste contractor licenses may be denied, modified, or revoked by the town after notice and hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application. 
(2)  Any material violation of this article including payment of fees, or failure to meet any other licensing requirements after notice and opportunity to cure within the reasonable time specified by the town. 
(3)  Conducting a business in violation of any federal, state, county or local law, including Title 49 Arizona Revised Statutes. 
(4)  The licensee is convicted of untrue, fraudulent, misleading or deceptive advertising. 
(5)  The licensee is a corporation and is no longer qualified to transact business in the state. 
(6)  Willful, grossly negligent, or repeated violations of this article, the license, or any other applicable law or regulation relating to the provision of solid waste collection services. 
(b)  A license shall not be revoked, if the licensee's violation of the license is the result of force majeure. 
(Ord. No. 1820, § I, 8-29-06) 
Sec. 66-319. - Denial of license application; appeal.
